text: CHAPTER VI. - OF MIRACLES.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) As men are accustomed to call Divine the knowledge which transcends
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human understanding, so also do they style Divine, or the work of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything of which the cause is not generally known: for the masses think
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the power and providence of God are most clearly displayed by events
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that are extraordinary and contrary to the conception they have formed of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, especially if such events bring them any profit or convenience: they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think that the clearest possible proof of God's existence is afforded when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, as they suppose, breaks her accustomed order, and consequently they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe that those who explain or endeavour to understand phenomena or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles through their natural causes are doing away with God and His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: providence. (2) They suppose, forsooth, that God is inactive so long as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature works in her accustomed order, and vice versa, that the power of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature and natural causes are idle so long as God is acting: thus they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagine two powers distinct one from the other, the power of God and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of nature, though the latter is in a sense determined by God, or (as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most people believe now) created by Him. (3) What they mean by either, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what they understand by God and nature they do not know, except that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagine the power of God to be like that of some royal potentate, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature's power to consist in force and energy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (4) The masses then style unusual phenomena, "miracles," and partly from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety, partly for the sake of opposing the students of science, prefer to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remain in ignorance of natural causes, and only to hear of those things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they know least, and consequently admire most. (5) In fact, the common
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people can only adore God, and refer all things to His power by removing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural causes, and conceiving things happening out of their due course, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only admires the power of God when the power of nature is conceived of as in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjection to it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) This idea seems to have taken its rise among the early Jews who saw the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Gentiles round them worshipping visible gods such as the sun, the moon, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earth, water, air, &c., and in order to inspire the conviction that such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divinities were weak and inconstant, or changeable, told how they themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were under the sway of an invisible God, and narrated their miracles,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: trying further to show that the God whom they worshipped arranged the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature for their sole benefit: this idea was so pleasing to humanity that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men go on to this day imagining miracles, so that they may believe
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves God's favourites, and the final cause for which God created and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directs all things.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) What pretension will not people in their folly advance! (8) They have no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: single sound idea concerning either God or nature, they confound God's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees with human decrees, they conceive nature as so limited that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe man to be its chief part! (9) I have spent enough space in setting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth these common ideas and prejudices concerning nature and miracles, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in order to afford a regular demonstration I will show -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (10) I. That nature cannot be contravened, but that she preserves a fixed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and immutable order, and at the same time I will explain what is meant by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracle.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (11) II. That God's nature and existence, and consequently His providence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be known from miracles, but that they can all be much better
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived from the fixed and immutable order of nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) III. That by the decrees and volitions, and consequently the providence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, Scripture (as I will prove by Scriptural examples) means nothing but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature's order following necessarily from her eternal laws.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) IV. Lastly, I will treat of the method of interpreting Scriptural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles, and the chief points to be noted concerning the narratives of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (14) Such are the principal subjects which will be discussed in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chapter, and which will serve, I think, not a little to further the object
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this treatise.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (15) Our first point is easily proved from what we showed in Chap. IV. about
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine law - namely, that all that God wishes or determines involves eternal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity, and truth, for we demonstrated that God's understanding is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: identical with His will, and that it is the same thing to say that God wills
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing, as to say, that He understands it; hence, as it follows
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily, from the Divine nature and perfection that God understands a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing as it is, it follows no less necessarily that He wills it as it is.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16) Now, as nothing is necessarily true save only by, Divine decree, it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain that the universal laws of nature are decrees of God following from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity and perfection of the Divine nature. (17) Hence, any event
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happening in nature which contravened nature's universal laws, would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily also contravene the Divine decree, nature, and understanding; or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if anyone asserted that God acts in contravention to the laws of nature, he,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ipso facto, would be compelled to assert that God acted against His own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature - an evident absurdity. (18) One might easily show from the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: premises that the power and efficiency, of nature are in themselves the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine power and efficiency, and that the Divine power is the very essence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, but this I gladly pass over for the present.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19) Nothing, then, comes to pass in nature (N.B. I do not mean here by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "nature," merely matter and its modifications, but infinite other things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: besides matter.) in contravention to her universal laws, nay, everything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agrees with them and follows from them, for whatsoever comes to pass, comes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to pass by the will and eternal decree of God; that is, as we have just
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed out, whatever comes to pass, comes to pass according to laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rules which involve eternal necessity and truth; nature, therefore, always
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observes laws and rules which involve eternal necessity, and truth, although
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they may not all be known to us, and therefore she keeps a fixed and mutable
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order. (20) Nor is there any sound reason for limiting the power and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: efficacy of nature, and asserting that her laws are fit for certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: purposes, but not for all; for as the efficacy, and power of nature, are the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very, efficacy and power of God, and as the laws and rules of nature are the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees of God, it is in every way to be believed that the power of nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is infinite, and that her laws are broad enough to embrace everything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived by, the Divine intellect; the only alternative is to assert that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God has created nature so weak, and has ordained for her laws so barren,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He is repeatedly compelled to come afresh to her aid if He wishes that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: she should be preserved, and that things should happen as He desires: a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion, in My opinion, very far removed from reason. (21) Further, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing happens in nature which does not follow from her laws, and as her
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws embrace everything conceived by the Divine intellect, and lastly, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature preserves a fixed and immutable order; it most clearly follows that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles are only intelligible as in relation to human opinions, and merely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean events of which the natural cause cannot be explained by a reference to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any ordinary occurrence, either by us, or at any rate, by the writer and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrator of the miracle.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (22) We may, in fact, say that a miracle is an event of which the causes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: annot be explained by the natural reason through a reference to ascertained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: workings of nature; but since miracles were wrought according to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding of the masses, who are wholly ignorant of the workings of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, it is certain that the ancients took for a miracle whatever they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could not explain by the method adopted by the unlearned in such cases,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, an appeal to the memory, a recalling of something similar, which is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinarily regarded without wonder; for most people think they sufficiently
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand a thing when they have ceased to wonder at it. (23) The ancients,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, and indeed most men up to the present day, had no other criterion for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a miracle; hence we cannot doubt that many things are narrated in Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as miracles of which the causes could easily be explained by reference to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ascertained workings of nature. (24) We have hinted as much in Chap. II., in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking of the sun standing still in the time of Joshua, and to say on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject when we come to treat of the interpretation of miracles later on in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (25) It is now time to pass on to the second point, and show that we cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gain an understanding of God's essence, existence, or providence by means of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles, but that these truths are much better perceived through the fixed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and immutable order of nature. (26) I thus proceed with the demonstration.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (27) As God's existence is not self-evident (6) it must necessarily be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inferred from ideas so firmly and incontrovertibly true, that no power can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be postulated or conceived sufficient to impugn them. (28) They ought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly so to appear to us when we infer from them God's existence, if we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wish to place our conclusion beyond the reach of doubt; for if we could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive that such ideas could be impugned by any power whatsoever, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should doubt of their truth, we should doubt of our conclusion, namely, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's existence, and should never be able to be certain of anything. (29)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, we know that nothing either agrees with or is contrary to nature,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless it agrees with or is contrary to these primary ideas; wherefore if we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would conceive that anything could be done in nature by any power whatsoever
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would be contrary to the laws of nature, it would also be contrary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our primary ideas, and we should have either to reject it as absurd, or else
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to cast doubt (as just shown) on our primary ideas, and consequently on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of God, and on everything howsoever perceived. (30) Therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles, in the sense of events contrary to the laws of nature, so far from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrating to us the existence of God, would, on the contrary, lead us to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt it, where, otherwise, we might have been absolutely certain of it, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowing that nature follows a fixed and immutable order.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (31) Let us take miracle as meaning that which cannot be explained through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural causes. (32) This may be interpreted in two senses: either as that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has natural causes, but cannot be examined by the human intellect; or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as that which has no cause save God and God's will. (33) But as all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which come to pass through natural causes, come to pass also solely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the will and power of God, it comes to this, that a miracle, whether
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it has natural causes or not, is a result which cannot be explained by its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause, that is a phenomenon which surpasses human understanding; but from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a phenomenon, and certainly from a result surpassing our understanding,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we can gain no knowledge. (34) For whatsoever we understand clearly and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly should be plain to us either in itself or by means of something
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else clearly and distinctly understood; wherefore from a miracle or a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomenon which we cannot understand, we can gain no knowledge of God's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence, or existence, or indeed anything about God or nature; whereas when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we know that all things are ordained and ratified by God, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: operations of nature follow from the essence of God, and that the laws of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature are eternal decrees and volitions of God, we must perforce conclude
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that our knowledge of God, and of God's will increases in proportion to our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge and clear understanding of nature, as we see how she depends on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: her primal cause, and how she works according to eternal law. (35) Wherefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as our understanding goes, those phenomena which we clearly and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly understand have much better right to be called works of God, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be referred to the will of God than those about which we are entirely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant, although they appeal powerfully to the imagination, and compel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men's admiration.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (36) It is only phenomena that we clearly and distinctly understand, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heighten our knowledge of God, and most clearly indicate His will and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees. (37) Plainly, they are but triflers who, when they cannot explain a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, run back to the will of God; this is, truly, a ridiculous way of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expressing ignorance. (38) Again, even supposing that some conclusion could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be drawn from miracles, we could not possibly infer from them the existence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God: for a miracle being an event under limitations is the expression of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a fixed and limited power; therefore we could not possibly infer from an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect of this kind the existence of a cause whose power is infinite, but at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the utmost only of a cause whose power is greater than that of the said
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect. (39) I say at the utmost, for a phenomenon may be the result of many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concurrent causes, and its power may be less than the power of the sum of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such causes, but far greater than that of any one of them taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individually. (40) On the other hand, the laws of nature, as we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown, extend over infinity, and are conceived by us as, after a fashion,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal, and nature works in accordance with them in a fixed and immutable
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order; therefore, such laws indicate to us in a certain degree the infinity,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the eternity, and the immutability of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) We may conclude, then, that we cannot gain knowledge of the existence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and providence of God by means of miracles, but that we can far better infer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them from the fixed and immutable order of nature. (41) By miracle, I here
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean an event which surpasses, or is thought to surpass, human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehension: for in so far as it is supposed to destroy or interrupt the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature or her laws, it not only can give us no knowledge of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but, contrariwise, takes away that which we naturally have, and makes us
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt of God and everything else.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) Neither do I recognize any difference between an event against the laws
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature and an event beyond the laws of nature (that is, according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some, an event which does not contravene nature, though she is inadequate to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: produce or effect it) - for a miracle is wrought in, and not beyond nature,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though it may be said in itself to be above nature, and, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must necessarily interrupt the order of nature, which otherwise we conceive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of as fixed and unchangeable, according to God's decrees. (43) If,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, anything should come to pass in nature which does not follow from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: her laws, it would also be in contravention to the order which God has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: established in nature for ever through universal natural laws: it would,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, be in contravention to God's nature and laws, and, consequently,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belief in it would throw doubt upon everything, and lead to Atheism.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (44) I think I have now sufficiently established my second point, so that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can again conclude that a miracle, whether in contravention to, or beyond,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, is a mere absurdity; and, therefore, that what is meant in Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by a miracle can only be a work of nature, which surpasses, or is believed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to surpass, human comprehension. (45) Before passing on to my third point, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will adduce Scriptural authority for my assertion that God cannot be known
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from miracles. (46) Scripture nowhere states the doctrine openly, but it can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily be inferred from several passages. (47) Firstly, that in which Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commands (Deut. xiii.) that a false prophet should be put to death, even
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though he work miracles: "If there arise a prophet among you, and giveth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thee a sign or wonder, and the sign or wonder come to pass, saying, Let us
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: go after other gods . . . thou shalt not hearken unto the voice of that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet; for the Lord your God proveth you, and that prophet shall be put to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: death." (48) From this it clearly follows that miracles could be wrought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even by false prophets; and that, unless men are honestly endowed with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true knowledge and love of God, they may be as easily led by miracles to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow false gods as to follow the true God; for these words are added: "For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord your God tempts you, that He may know whether you love Him with all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: your heart and with all your mind."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (49) Further, the Israelites, from all their miracles, were unable to form a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sound conception of God, as their experience testified: for when they had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuaded themselves that Moses had departed from among them, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: petitioned Aaron to give them visible gods; and the idea of God they had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formed as the result of all their miracles was - a calf!
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (50) Asaph, though he had heard of so many miracles, yet doubted of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: providence of God, and would have turned himself from the true way, if he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had not at last come to understand true blessedness. (See Ps. lxxxiii.) (51)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Solomon, too, at a time when the Jewish nation was at the height of its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prosperity, suspects that all things happen by chance. (See Eccles. iii:19,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 20, 21; and chap. ix:2, 3, &c.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (52) Lastly, nearly all the prophets found it very hard to reconcile the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature and human affairs with the conception they had formed of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's providence, whereas philosophers who endeavour to understand things by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear conceptions of them, rather than by miracles, have always found the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: task extremely easy - at least, such of them as place true happiness solely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in virtue and peace of mind, and who aim at obeying nature, rather than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being obeyed by her. (53) Such persons rest assured that God directs nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the requirements of universal laws, not according to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requirements of the particular laws of human nature, and trial, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's scheme comprehends, not only the human race, but the whole of nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (54) It is plain, then, from Scripture itself, that miracles can give no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God, nor clearly teach us the providence of God. (55) As to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frequent statements in Scripture, that God wrought miracles to make Himself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain to man - as in Exodus x:2, where He deceived the Egyptians, and gave
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signs of Himself, that the Israelites might know that He was God,- it does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not, therefore, follow that miracles really taught this truth, but only that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews held opinions which laid them easily open to conviction by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles. (56) We have shown in Chap. II. that the reasons assigned by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets, or those which are formed from revelation, are not assigned
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in accordance with ideas universal and common to all, but in accordance with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the accepted doctrines, however absurd, and with the opinions of those to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whom the revelation was given, or those whom the Holy Spirit wished to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convince.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (57) This we have illustrated by many Scriptural instances, and can further
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cite Paul, who to the Greeks was a Greek, and to the Jews a Jew. (58) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although these miracles could convince the Egyptians and Jews from their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: standpoint, they could not give a true idea and knowledge of God, but only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause them to admit that there was a Deity more powerful than anything known
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to them, and that this Deity took special care of the Jews, who had just
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then an unexpectedly happy issue of all their affairs. (59) They could not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teach them that God cares equally for all, for this can be taught only by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosophy: the Jews, and all who took their knowledge of God's providence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the dissimilarity of human conditions of life and the inequalities of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortune, persuaded themselves that God loved the Jews above all men, though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they did not surpass their fellows in true human perfection.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) I now go on to my third point, and show from Scripture that the decrees
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and mandates of God, and consequently His providence, are merely the order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature - that is, when Scripture describes an event as accomplished by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God or God's will, we must understand merely that it was in accordance with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the law and order of nature, not, as most people believe, that nature had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for a season ceased to act, or that her order was temporarily interrupted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (61) But Scripture does not directly teach matters unconnected with its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine, wherefore it has no care to explain things by their natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, nor to expound matters merely speculative. (62) Wherefore our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion must be gathered by inference from those Scriptural narratives
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which happen to be written more at length and circumstantially than usual.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) Of these I will cite a few.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (64) In the first book of Samuel, ix:15, 16, it is related that God revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to Samuel that He would send Saul to him, yet God did not send Saul to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Samuel as people are wont to send one man to another. (65) His "sending" was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely the ordinary course of nature. (66) Saul was looking for the asses he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had lost, and was meditating a return home without them, when, at the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suggestion of his servant, he went to the prophet Samuel, to learn from him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where he might find them. (67) From no part of the narrative does it appear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Saul had any command from God to visit Samuel beyond this natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motive.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) In Psalm cv. 24 it is said that God changed the hearts of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Egyptians, so that they hated the Israelites. (69) This was evidently a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural change, as appears from Exodus, chap.i., where we find no slight
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason for the Egyptians reducing the Israelites to slavery.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (70) In Genesis ix:13, God tells Noah that He will set His bow in the cloud;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this action of God's is but another way of expressing the refraction and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reflection which the rays of the sun are subjected to in drops of water.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) In Psalm cxlvii:18, the natural action and warmth of the wind, by which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hoar frost and snow are melted, are styled the word of the Lord, and in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: verse 15 wind and cold are called the commandment and word of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (72) In Psalm civ:4, wind and fire are called the angels and ministers of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and various other passages of the same sort are found in Scripture,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly showing that the decree, commandment, fiat, and word of God are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely expressions for the action and order of nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (73) Thus it is plain that all the events narrated in Scripture came to pass
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: naturally, and are referred directly to God because Scripture, as we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown, does not aim at explaining things by their natural causes, but only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at narrating what appeals to the popular imagination, and doing so in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner best calculated to excite wonder, and consequently to impress the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: minds of the masses with devotion. (74) If, therefore, events are found in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Bible which we cannot refer to their causes, nay, which seem entirely to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradict the order of nature, we must not come to a stand, but assuredly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe that whatever did really happen happened naturally. (75) This view
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is confirmed by the fact that in the case of every miracle there were many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attendant circumstances, though these were not always related, especially
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where the narrative was of a poetic character.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (76) The circumstances of the miracles clearly show, I maintain, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural causes were needed. (77) For instance, in order to infect the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Egyptians with blains, it was necessary that Moses should scatter ashes in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the air (Exod. ix: 10); the locusts also came upon the land of Egypt by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: command of God in accordance with nature, namely, by an east wind blowing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for a whole day and night; and they departed by a very strong west wind
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Exod. x:14, 19). (78) By a similar Divine mandate the sea opened a way for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews (Exo. xiv:21), namely, by an east wind which blew very strongly all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: night.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (79) So, too, when Elisha would revive the boy who was believed to be dead,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he was obliged to bend over him several times until the flesh of the child
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: waxed warm, and at last he opened his eyes (2 Kings iv:34, 35).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) Again, in John's Gospel (chap. ix.) certain acts are mentioned as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: performed by Christ preparatory to healing the blind man, and there are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: numerous other instances showing that something further than the absolute
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fiat of God is required for working a miracle.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) Wherefore we may believe that, although the circumstances attending
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles are not related always or in full detail, yet a miracle was never
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: performed without them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (82) This is confirmed by Exodus xiv:27, where it is simply stated that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Moses stretched forth his hand, and the waters of the sea returned to their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength in the morning," no mention being made of a wind; but in the song
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Moses (Exod. xv:10) we read, "Thou didst blow with Thy wind (i.e. with a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very strong wind), and the sea covered them." (83) Thus the attendant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstance is omitted in the history, and the miracle is thereby enhanced.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (84) But perhaps someone will insist that we find many things in Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which seem in nowise explicable by natural causes, as for instance, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sins of men and their prayers can be the cause of rain and of the earth's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fertility, or that faith can heal the blind, and so on. (85) But I think
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have already made sufficient answer: I have shown that Scripture does not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain things by their secondary causes, but only narrates them in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order and the style which has most power to move men, and especially
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uneducated men, to devotion; and therefore it speaks inaccurately of God and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of events, seeing that its object is not to convince the reason, but to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attract and lay hold of the imagination. (86) If the Bible were to describe
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the destruction of an empire in the style of political historians, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: masses would remain unstirred, whereas the contrary is the case when it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adopts the method of poetic description, and refers all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: immediately to God. (87) When, therefore, the Bible says that the earth is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: barren because of men's sins, or that the blind were healed by faith, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ought to take no more notice than when it says that God is angry at men's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sins, that He is sad, that He repents of the good He has promised and done;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or that on seeing a sign he remembers something He had promised, and other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar expressions, which are either thrown out poetically or related
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the opinion and prejudices of the writer.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (88) We may, then, be absolutely certain that every event which is truly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: described in Scripture necessarily happened, like everything else, according
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to natural laws; and if anything is there set down which can be proved in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set terms to contravene the order of nature, or not to be deducible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom, we must believe it to have been foisted into the sacred writings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by irreligious hands; for whatsoever is contrary to nature is also contrary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to reason, and whatsoever is contrary to reason is absurd, and, ipso facto,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be rejected.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (89) There remain some points concerning the interpretation of miracles to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be noted, or rather to be recapitulated, for most of them have been already
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stated. (90) These I proceed to discuss in the fourth division of my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject, and I am led to do so lest anyone should, by wrongly interpreting a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracle, rashly suspect that he has found something in Scripture contrary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (91) It is very rare for men to relate an event simply as it happened,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without adding any element of their own judgment. (92) When they see or hear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything new, they are, unless strictly on their guard, so occupied with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own preconceived opinions that they perceive something quite
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from the plain facts seen or heard, especially if such facts
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpass the comprehension of the beholder or hearer, and, most of all, if he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is interested in their happening in a given way.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (93) Thus men relate in chronicles and histories their own opinions rather
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than actual events, so that one and the same event is so differently related
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by two men of different opinions, that it seems like two separate
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occurrences; and, further, it is very easy from historical chronicles to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gather the personal opinions of the historian.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) I could cite many instances in proof of this from the writings both of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural philosophers and historians, but I will content myself with one only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Scripture, and leave the reader to judge of the rest.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (95) In the time of Joshua the Hebrews held the ordinary opinion that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sun moves with a daily motion, and that the earth remains at rest; to this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preconceived opinion they adapted the miracle which occurred during their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: battle with the five kings. (96) They did not simply relate that that day
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was longer than usual, but asserted that the sun and moon stood still, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ceased from their motion - a statement which would be of great service to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them at that time in convincing and proving by experience to the Gentiles,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who worshipped the sun, that the sun was under the control of another deity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who could compel it to change its daily course. (97) Thus, partly through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religious motives, partly through preconceived opinions, they conceived of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and related the occurrence as something quite different from what really
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happened.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (98) Thus in order to interpret the Scriptural miracles and understand from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the narration of them how they really happened, it is necessary to know the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions of those who first related them, and have recorded them for us in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writing, and to distinguish such opinions from the actual impression made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: upon their senses, otherwise we shall confound opinions and judgments with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the actual miracle as it really occurred: nay, further, we shall confound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual events with symbolical and imaginary ones. (99) For many things are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrated in Scripture as real, and were believed to be real, which were in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact only symbolical and imaginary. (100) As, for instance, that God came
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down from heaven (Exod. xix:28, Deut. v:28), and that Mount Sinai smoked
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because God descended upon it surrounded with fire; or, again that Elijah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ascended into heaven in a chariot of fire, with horses of fire; all these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things were assuredly merely symbols adapted to the opinions of those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have handed them down to us as they were represented to them, namely, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real. (101) All who have any education know that God has no right hand nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: left; that He is not moved nor at rest, nor in a particular place, but that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He is absolutely infinite and contains in Himself all perfections.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (102) These things, I repeat, are known to whoever judges of things by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception of pure reason, and not according as his imagination is affected
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by his outward senses. (103) Following the example of the masses who imagine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a bodily Deity, holding a royal court with a throne on the convexity of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heaven, above the stars, which are believed to be not very, far off from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earth.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) To these and similar opinions very many narrations in Scripture are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adapted, and should not, therefore, be mistaken by philosophers for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: realities.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (105) Lastly, in order to understand, in the case of miracles, what actually
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: took place, we ought to be familiar with Jewish phrases and metaphors;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone who did not make sufficient allowance for these, would be continually
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seeing miracles in Scripture where nothing of the kind is intended by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writer; he would thus miss the knowledge not only of what actually happened,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but also of the mind of the writers of the sacred text. (106) For instance,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Zechariah speaking of some future war says (chap. xiv:7): "It shall be one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day which shall be known to the Lord, not day, nor night; but at even time
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it shall be light." In these words he seems to predict a great miracle, yet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he only means that the battle will be doubtful the whole day, that the issue
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be known only to God, but that in the evening they will gain the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: victory: the prophets frequently used to predict victories and defeats of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nations in similar phrases. (107) Thus Isaiah, describing the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destruction of Babylon, says (chap. xiii.): "The stars of heaven, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constellations thereof, shall not give their light; the sun shall be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: darkened in his going forth, and the moon shall not cause her light to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shine." (108) Now I suppose no one imagines that at the destruction of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Babylon these phenomena actually occurred any more than that which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet adds, "For I will make the heavens to tremble, and remove the earth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out of her place."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (109) So, too, Isaiah in foretelling to the Jews that they would return from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Babylon to Jerusalem in safety, and would not suffer from thirst on their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: journey, says: "And they thirsted not when He led them through the deserts;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He caused the waters to flow out of the rocks for them; He clave the rocks,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the waters gushed out." (110) These words merely mean that the Jews,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like other people, found springs in the desert, at which they quenched their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thirst; for when the Jews returned to Jerusalem with the consent of Cyrus,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is admitted that no similar miracles befell them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (111) In this way many occurrences in the Bible are to be regarded merely as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jewish expressions. (112) There is no need for me to go through them in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: detail; but I will call attention generally to the fact that the Jews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employed such phrases not only rhetorically, but also, and indeed chiefly,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from devotional motives. (113) Such is the reason for the substitution of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "bless God" for "curse God" in 1 Kings xxi:10, and Job ii:9, and for all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things being referred to God, whence it appears that the Bible seems to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: relate nothing but miracles, even when speaking of the most ordinary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occurrences, as in the examples given above.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (114) Hence we must believe that when the Bible says that the Lord hardened
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharaoh's heart, it only means that Pharaoh was obstinate; when it says that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God opened the windows of heaven, it only means that it rained very hard,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and so on. (115) When we reflect on these peculiarities, and also on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact that most things are related very shortly, with very little details and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: almost in abridgments, we shall see that there is hardly anything in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture which can be proved contrary to natural reason, while, on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other hand, many things which before seemed obscure, will after a little
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration be understood and easily explained.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (116) I think I have now very clearly explained all that I proposed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain, but before I finish this chapter I would call attention to the fact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I have adopted a different method in speaking of miracles to that which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I employed in treating of prophecy. (117) Of prophecy I have asserted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing which could not be inferred from promises revealed in Scripture,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas in this chapter I have deduced my conclusions solely from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principles ascertained by the natural light of reason. (118) I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proceeded in this way advisedly, for prophecy, in that it surpasses human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, is a purely theological question; therefore, I knew that I could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not make any assertions about it, nor learn wherein it consists, except
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through deductions from premises that have been revealed; therefore I was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled to collate the history of prophecy, and to draw therefrom certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusions which would teach me, in so far as such teaching is possible,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature and properties of the gift. (119) But in the case of miracles, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our inquiry is a question purely philosophical (namely, whether anything can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happen which contravenes or does not follow from the laws of nature), I was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not under any such necessity: I therefore thought it wiser to unravel the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: difficulty through premises ascertained and thoroughly known by could also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily have solved the problem merely from the doctrines and fundamental
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principles of Scripture: in order that everyone may acknowledge this, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: briefly show how it could be done.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (120) Scripture makes the general assertion in several passages that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature's course is fixed and unchangeable. (121) In Ps. cxlviii:6, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, and Jer. xxxi:35. (122) The wise man also, in Eccles. i:10,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly teaches that "there is nothing new under the sun," and in verses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 11, 12, illustrating the same idea, he adds that although something
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occasionally happens which seems new, it is not really new, but "hath been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already of old time, which was before us, whereof there is no remembrance,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those that come after." (123) Again in chap. iii:11, he says, "God hath made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything beautiful in his time," and immediately afterwards adds, "I know
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that whatsoever God doeth, it shall be for ever; nothing can be put to it,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor anything taken from it."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (124) Now all these texts teach most distinctly that nature preserves a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fixed and unchangeable order, and that God in all ages, known and unknown,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been the same; further, that the laws of nature are so perfect, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing can be added thereto nor taken therefrom; and, lastly, that miracles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only appear as something new because of man's ignorance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (125) Such is the express teaching of Scripture: nowhere does Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assert that anything happens which contradicts, or cannot follow from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of nature; and, therefore, we should not attribute to it such a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
