text: (126) To these considerations we must add, that miracles require causes and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attendant circumstances, and that they follow, not from some mysterious
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: royal power which the masses attribute to God, but from the Divine rule and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree, that is (as we have shown from Scripture itself) from the laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature; lastly, that miracles can be wrought even by false
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets, as is proved from Deut. xiii. and Matt. xxiv:24.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (127) The conclusion, then, that is most plainly put before us is, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles were natural occurrences, and must therefore be so explained as to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appear neither new (in the words of Solomon) nor contrary to nature, but, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as possible, in complete agreement with ordinary events. (128) This can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily be done by anyone, now that I have set forth the rules drawn from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture. (129) Nevertheless, though I maintain that Scripture teaches this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine, I do not assert that it teaches it as a truth necessary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: salvation, but only that the prophets were in agreement with ourselves on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the point; therefore everyone is free to think on the subject as he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: likes, according as he thinks it best for himself, and most likely to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduce to the worship of God and to singlehearted religion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (130) This is also the opinion of Josephus, for at the conclusion of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: second book of his "Antiquities," he writes: Let no man think this story
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: incredible of the sea's dividing to save these people, for we find it in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ancient records that this hath been seen before, whether by God's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extraordinary will or by the course of nature it is indifferent. (131) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same thing happened one time to the Macedonians, under the command of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Alexander, when for want of another passage the Pamphylian Sea divided to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make them way; God's Providence making use of Alexander at that time as His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instrument for destroying the Persian Empire. (132) This is attested by all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the historians who have pretended to write the Life of that Prince. (133)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But people are at liberty to think what they please."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (134) Such are the words of Josephus, and such is his opinion on faith in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER VII. - OF THE INTERPRETATION OF SCRIPTURE
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) When people declare, as all are ready, to do, that the Bible is the Word
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God teaching man true blessedness and the way of salvation, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evidently do not mean what they, say; for the masses take no pains at all to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live according to Scripture, and we see most people endeavouring to hawk
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about their own commentaries as the word of God, and giving their best
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: efforts, under the guise of religion, to compelling others to think as they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do: we generally see, I say, theologians anxious to learn how to wring their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inventions and sayings out of the sacred text, and to fortify, them with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine authority. (2) Such persons never display, less scruple or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more zeal than when they, are interpreting Scripture or the mind of the Holy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ghost; if we ever see them perturbed, it is not that they fear to attribute
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some error to the Holy Spirit, and to stray from the right path, but that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are afraid to be convicted of error by, others, and thus to overthrow
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and bring into contempt their own authority. (3) But if men really believed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what they verbally testify of Scripture, they would adopt quite a different
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plan of life: their minds would not be agitated by so many contentions, nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so many hatreds, and they would cease to be excited by such a blind and rash
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion for interpreting the sacred writings, and excogitating novelties
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in religion. (4) On the contrary, they would not dare to adopt, as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teaching of Scripture, anything which they could not plainly deduce
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom: lastly, those sacrilegious persons who have dared, in several
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages, to interpolate the Bible, would have shrunk from so great a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: crime, and would have stayed their sacrilegious hands.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (5) Ambition and unscrupulousness have waxed so powerful, that religion is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought to consist, not so much in respecting the writings of the Holy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ghost, as in defending human commentaries, so that religion is no longer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: identified with charity, but with spreading discord and propagating
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insensate hatred disguised under the name of zeal for the Lord, and eager
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ardour.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) To these evils we must add superstition, which teaches men to despise
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason and nature, and only to admire and venerate that which is repugnant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to both: whence it is not wonderful that for the sake of increasing the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admiration and veneration felt for Scripture, men strive to explain it so as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to make it appear to contradict, as far as possible, both one and the other:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus they dream that most profound mysteries lie hid in the Bible, and weary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves out in the investigation of these absurdities, to the neglect of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is useful. (7) Every result of their diseased imagination they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute to the Holy Ghost, and strive to defend with the utmost zeal and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion; for it is an observed fact that men employ their reason to defend
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusions arrived at by reason, but conclusions arrived at by the passions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are defended by the passions.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (8) If we would separate ourselves from the crowd and escape from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theological prejudices, instead of rashly accepting human commentaries for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine documents, we must consider the true method of interpreting Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and dwell upon it at some length: for if we remain in ignorance of this we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot know, certainly, what the Bible and the Holy Spirit wish to teach.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9)I may sum up the matter by saying that the method of interpreting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture does not widely differ from the method of interpreting nature - in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, it is almost the same. (10) For as the interpretation of nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists in the examination of the history of nature, and therefrom
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deducing definitions of natural phenomena on certain fixed axioms, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural interpretation proceeds by the examination of Scripture, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inferring the intention of its authors as a legitimate conclusion from its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fundamental principles. (11) By working in this manner everyone will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always advance without danger of error - that is, if they admit no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principles for interpreting Scripture, and discussing its contents save such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they find in Scripture itself - and will be able with equal security to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discuss what surpasses our understanding, and what is known by the natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: light of reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) In order to make clear that such a method is not only correct, but is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also the only one advisable, and that it agrees with that employed in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreting nature, I must remark that Scripture very often treats of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters which cannot be deduced from principles known to reason: for it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chiefly made up of narratives and revelation: the narratives generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contain miracles - that is, as we have shown in the last chapter, relations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of extraordinary natural occurrences adapted to the opinions and judgment of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the historians who recorded them: the revelations also were adapted to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions of the prophets, as we showed in Chap. II., and in themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpassed human comprehension. (13) Therefore the knowledge of all these -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, of nearly the whole contents of Scripture, must be sought from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture alone, even as the knowledge of nature is sought from nature. (14)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As for the moral doctrines which are also contained in the Bible, they may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be demonstrated from received axioms, but we cannot prove in the same manner
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Scripture intended to teach them, this can only be learned from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture itself.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (15) If we would bear unprejudiced witness to the Divine origin of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture, we must prove solely on its own authority that it teaches true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moral doctrines, for by such means alone can its Divine origin be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrated: we have shown that the certitude of the prophets depended
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chiefly on their having minds turned towards what is just and good,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore we ought to have proof of their possessing this quality before we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repose faith in them. (16) From miracles God's divinity cannot be proved, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have already shown, and need not now repeat, for miracles could be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wrought by false prophets. (17) Wherefore the Divine origin of Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must consist solely in its teaching true virtue. (18) But we must come to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our conclusion simply on Scriptural grounds, for if we were unable to do so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we could not, unless strongly prejudiced accept the Bible and bear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: witness to its Divine origin.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19) Our knowledge of Scripture must then be looked for in Scripture only.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20) Lastly, Scripture does not give us definition of things any more than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature does: therefore, such definitions must be sought in the latter case
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the diverse workings of nature; in the former case, from the various
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narratives about the given subject which occur in the Bible.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) The universal rule, then, in interpreting Scripture is to accept
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing as an authoritative Scriptural statement which we do not perceive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very clearly when we examine it in the light of its history. (22) What I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean by its history, and what should be the chief points elucidated, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now explain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (23) The history of a Scriptural statement comprises -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (23) I. The nature and properties of the language in which the books of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bible were written, and in which their authors were, accustomed to speak.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) We shall thus be able to investigate every expression by comparison
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with common conversational usages.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (25) Now all the writers both of the Old Testament and the New were Hebrews:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, a knowledge of the Hebrew language is before all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary, not only for the comprehension of the Old Testament, which was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written in that tongue, but also of the New: for although the latter was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: published in other languages, yet its characteristics are Hebrew.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (26) II. An analysis of each book and arrangement of its contents under
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heads; so that we may have at hand the various texts which treat of a given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject. (27) Lastly, a note of all the passages which are ambiguous or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscure, or which seem mutually contradictory.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (28) I call passages clear or obscure according as their meaning is inferred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily or with difficulty in relation to the context, not according as their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth is perceived easily or the reverse by reason. (29) We are at work not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the truth of passages, but solely on their meaning. (30) We must take
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especial care, when we are in search of the meaning of a text, not to be led
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away by our reason in so far as it is founded on principles of natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge (to say nothing of prejudices): in order not to confound the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning of a passage with its truth, we must examine it solely by means of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the signification of the words, or by a reason acknowledging no foundation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but Scripture.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (31) I will illustrate my meaning by an example. (32) The words of Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "God is a fire" and "God is jealous," are perfectly clear so long as we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard merely the signification of the words, and I therefore reckon them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among the clear passages, though in relation to reason and truth they are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most obscure: still, although the literal meaning is repugnant to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural light of reason, nevertheless, if it cannot be clearly overruled on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grounds and principles derived from its Scriptural "history," it, that is,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the literal meaning, must be the one retained: and contrariwise if these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages literally interpreted are found to clash with principles derived
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Scripture, though such literal interpretation were in absolute harmony
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with reason, they must be interpreted in a different manner, i.e.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: metaphorically.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (33) If we would know whether Moses believed God to be a fire or not, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must on no account decide the question on grounds of the reasonableness or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the reverse of such an opinion, but must judge solely by the other opinions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Moses which are on record.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (34) In the present instance, as Moses says in several other passages that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God has no likeness to any visible thing, whether in heaven or in earth, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the water, either all such passages must be taken metaphorically, or else
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the one before us must be so explained. (35) However, as we should depart as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: little as possible from the literal sense, we must first ask whether this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: text, God is a fire, admits of any but the literal meaning - that is,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether the word fire ever means anything besides ordinary natural fire.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (36) If no such second meaning can be found, the text must be taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: literally, however repugnant to reason it may be: and all the other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages, though in complete accordance with reason, must be brought into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony with it. (37) If the verbal expressions would not admit of being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus harmonized, we should have to set them down as irreconcilable, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspend our judgment concerning them. (38) However, as we find the name fire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: applied to anger and jealousy (see Job xxxi:12) we can thus easily reconcile
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the words of Moses, and legitimately conclude that the two propositions God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a fire, and God is jealous, are in meaning identical.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (39) Further, as Moses clearly teaches that God is jealous, and nowhere
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states that God is without passions or emotions, we must evidently infer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Moses held this doctrine himself, or at any rate, that he wished to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teach it, nor must we refrain because such a belief seems contrary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason: for as we have shown, we cannot wrest the meaning of texts to suit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dictates of our reason, or our preconceived opinions. (40) The whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the Bible must be sought solely from itself.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (41) III. Lastly, such a history should relate the environment of all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophetic books extant; that is, the life, the conduct, and the studies of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the author of each book, who he was, what was the occasion, and the epoch of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his writing, whom did he write for, and in what language. (42) Further,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it should inquire into the fate of each book: how it was first received,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into whose hands it fell, how many different versions there were of it, by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whose advice was it received into the Bible, and, lastly, how all the books
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now universally accepted as sacred, were united into a single whole.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (43) All such information should, as I have said, be contained in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "history" of Scripture. (44) For, in order to know what statements are set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth as laws, and what as moral precepts, it is important to be acquainted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the life, the conduct, and the pursuits of their author: moreover,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it becomes easier to explain a man's writings in proportion as we have more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intimate knowledge of his genius and temperament.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) Further, that we may not confound precepts which are eternal with those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which served only a temporary purpose, or were only meant for a few, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should know what was the occasion, the time, the age, in which each book was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written, and to what nation it was addressed.(46) Lastly, we should have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge on the other points I have mentioned, in order to be sure,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in addition to the authenticity of the work, that it has not been tampered
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with by sacrilegious hands, or whether errors can have crept in, and, if so,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether they have been corrected by men sufficiently skilled and worthy of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: credence. (47) All these things should be known, that we may not be led away
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by blind impulse to accept whatever is thrust on our notice, instead of only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which is sure and indisputable.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (48) Now when we are in possession of this history of Scripture, and have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finally decided that we assert nothing as prophetic doctrine which does not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly follow from such history, or which is not clearly deducible from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, then, I say, it will be time to gird ourselves for the task of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: investigating the mind of the prophets and of the Holy Spirit. (49) But in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this further arguing, also, we shall require a method very like that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employed in interpreting nature from her history. (50) As in the examination
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of natural phenomena we try first to investigate what is most universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and common to all nature - such, for instance, as motion and rest, and their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws and rules, which nature always observes, and through which she
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continually works - and then we proceed to what is less universal; so, too,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the history of Scripture, we seek first for that which is most universal,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and serves for the basis and foundation of all Scripture, a doctrine, in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, that is commended by all the prophets as eternal and most profitable
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to all men. (51) For example, that God is one, and that He is omnipotent,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He alone should be worshipped, that He has a care for all men, and that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He especially loves those who adore Him and love their neighbour as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, &c. (52) These and similar doctrines, I repeat, Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everywhere so clearly and expressly teaches, that no one was ever in doubt
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its meaning concerning them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (53) The nature of God, His manner of regarding and providing for things,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and similar doctrines, Scripture nowhere teaches professedly, and as eternal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine; on the contrary, we have shown that the prophets themselves did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not agree on the subject; therefore, we must not lay down any doctrine as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural on such subjects, though it may appear perfectly clear on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rational grounds.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (54) From a proper knowledge of this universal doctrine of Scripture, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must then proceed to other doctrines less universal, but which,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless, have regard to the general conduct of life, and flow from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal doctrine like rivulets from a source; such are all particular
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external manifestations of true virtue, which need a given occasion for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their exercise; whatever is obscure or ambiguous on such points in Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be explained and defined by its universal doctrine; with regard to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradictory instances, we must observe the occasion and the time in which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they were written. (55) For instance, when Christ says, "Blessed are they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that mourn, for they shall be comforted" we do not know, from the actual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passage, what sort of mourners are meant; as, however, Christ afterwards
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teaches that we should have care for nothing, save only for the kingdom of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God and His righteousness, which is commended as the highest good (see
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Matt. vi:33), it follows that by mourners He only meant those who mourn for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the kingdom of God and righteousness neglected by man: for this would be the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only cause of mourning to those who love nothing but the Divine kingdom and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: justice, and who evidently despise the gifts of fortune. (56) So, too, when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Christ says: "But if a man strike you on the right cheek, turn to him the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: left also," and the words which follow.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (57) If He had given such a command, as a lawgiver, to judges, He would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereby have abrogated the law of Moses, but this He expressly says He did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not do (Matt. v:17). (58) Wherefore we must consider who was the speaker,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what was the occasion, and to whom were the words addressed. (59) Now Christ
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said that He did not ordain laws as a legislator, but inculcated precepts as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a teacher: inasmuch as He did not aim at correcting outward actions so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much as the frame of mind. (60) Further, these words were spoken to men who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were oppressed, who lived in a corrupt commonwealth on the brink of ruin,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where justice was utterly neglected. (61) The very doctrine inculcated here
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by Christ just before the destruction of the city was also taught by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeremiah before the first destruction of Jerusalem, that is, in similar
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances, as we see from Lamentations iii:25-30.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (62) Now as such teaching was only set forth by the prophets in times of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: oppression, and was even then never laid down as a law; and as, on the other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, Moses (who did not write in times of oppression, but - mark this -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strove to found a well-ordered commonwealth), while condemning envy and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred of one's neighbour, yet ordained that an eye should be given for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an eye, it follows most clearly from these purely Scriptural grounds that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this precept of Christ and Jeremiah concerning submission to injuries was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only valid in places where justice is neglected, and in a time of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: oppression, but does not hold good in a well-ordered state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) In a well-ordered state where justice is administered every one is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound, if he would be accounted just, to demand penalties before the judge
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (see Lev:1), not for the sake of vengeance (Lev. xix:17, 18), but in order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to defend justice and his country's laws, and to prevent the wicked
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rejoicing in their wickedness. (64) All this is plainly in accordance with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason. (65) I might cite many other examples in the same manner, but I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think the foregoing are sufficient to explain my meaning and the utility of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this method, and this is all my present purpose. (66) Hitherto we have only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown how to investigate those passages of Scripture which treat of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practical conduct, and which, therefore, are more easily examined, for on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such subjects there was never really any controversy among the writers of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Bible.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (67) The purely speculative passages cannot be so easily, traced to their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real meaning: the way becomes narrower, for as the prophets differed in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters speculative among themselves, and the narratives are in great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: measure adapted to the prejudices of each age, we must not, on any, account
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infer the intention of one prophet from clearer passages in the writings of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another; nor must we so explain his meaning, unless it is perfectly plain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the two prophets were at one in the matter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) How we are to arrive at the intention of the prophets in such cases I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will briefly explain. (69) Here, too, we must begin from the most universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition, inquiring first from the most clear Scriptural statements what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the nature of prophecy or revelation, and wherein does it consist; then
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we must proceed to miracles, and so on to whatever is most general till we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: come to the opinions of a particular prophet, and, at last, to the meaning
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a particular revelation, prophecy, history, or miracle. (70) We have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already pointed out that great caution is necessary not to confound the mind
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a prophet or historian with the mind of the Holy Spirit and the truth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the matter; therefore I need not dwell further on the subject. (71) I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would, however, here remark concerning the meaning of revelation, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present method only teaches us what the prophets really saw or heard, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what they desired to signify or represent by symbols. (72) The latter may be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guessed at but cannot be inferred with certainty from Scriptural premises.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (73) We have thus shown the plan for interpreting Scripture, and have, at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same time, demonstrated that it is the one and surest way of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: investigating its true meaning. (74) I am willing indeed to admit that those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persons (if any such there be) would be more absolutely certainly right, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have received either a trustworthy tradition or an assurance from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets themselves, such as is claimed by the Pharisees; or who have a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pontiff gifted with infallibility in the interpretation of Scripture, such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the Roman Catholics boast. (75) But as we can never be perfectly sure,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either of such a tradition or of the authority of the pontiff, we cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: found any certain conclusion on either: the one is denied by the oldest sect
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Christians, the other by the oldest sect of Jews. (76) Indeed, if we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider the series of years (to mention no other point) accepted by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharisees from their Rabbis, during which time they say they have handed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down the tradition from Moses, we shall find that it is not correct, as I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show elsewhere. (77) Therefore such a tradition should be received with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extreme suspicion; and although, according to our method, we are bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider as uncorrupted the tradition of the Jews, namely, the meaning of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Hebrew words which we received from them, we may accept the latter while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retaining our doubts about the former.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (78) No one has ever been able to change the meaning of a word in ordinary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: use, though many have changed the meaning of a particular sentence. (79)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such a proceeding would be most difficult; for whoever attempted to change
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the meaning of a word, would be compelled, at the same time, to explain all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the authors who employed it, each according to his temperament and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intention, or else, with consummate cunning, to falsify them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) Further, the masses and the learned alike preserve language, but it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only the learned who preserve the meaning of particular sentences and books:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus, we may easily imagine that the learned having a very rare book in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their power, might change or corrupt the meaning of a sentence in it, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they could not alter the signification of the words; moreover, if anyone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wanted to change the meaning of a common word he would not be able to keep
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: up the change among posterity, or in common parlance or writing.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) For these and such-like reasons we may readily conclude that it would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never enter into the mind of anyone to corrupt a language, though the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intention of a writer may often have been falsified by changing his phrases
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or interpreting them amiss. (82) As then our method (based on the principle
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the knowledge of Scripture must be sought from itself alone) is the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sole true one, we must evidently renounce any knowledge which it cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: furnish for the complete understanding of Scripture. (83) I will now point
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out its difficulties and shortcomings, which prevent our gaining a complete
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and assured knowledge of the Sacred Text.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (84) Its first great difficulty consists in its requiring a thorough
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the Hebrew language. (85) Where is such knowledge to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obtained? (86) The men of old who employed the Hebrew tongue have left none
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the principles and bases of their language to posterity; we have from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them absolutely nothing in the way of dictionary, grammar, or rhetoric.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (87) Now the Hebrew nation has lost all its grace and beauty (as one would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expect after the defeats and persecutions it has gone through), and has only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retained certain fragments of its language and of a few books. (88) Nearly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the names of fruits, birds, and fishes, and many other words have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perished in the wear and tear of time. (89) Further, the meaning of many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nouns and verbs which occur in the Bible are either utterly lost, or are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects of dispute. (90) And not only are these gone, but we are lacking in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a knowledge of Hebrew phraseology. (91) The devouring tooth of time has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed turns of expression peculiar to the Hebrews, so that we know them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no more.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (92) Therefore we cannot investigate as we would all the meanings of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sentence by the uses of the language; and there are many phrases of which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the meaning is most obscure or altogether inexplicable, though the component
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words are perfectly plain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (93) To this impossibility of tracing the history of the Hebrew language
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be added its particular nature and composition: these give rise to so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many ambiguities that it is impossible to find a method which would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enable us to gain a certain knowledge of all the statements in Scripture,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 7]. (94) In addition to the sources of ambiguities common to all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: languages, there are many peculiar to Hebrew. (95) These, I think, it worth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while to mention.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (96) Firstly, an ambiguity often arises in the Bible from our mistaking one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: letter for another similar one. (97) The Hebrews divide the letters of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alphabet into five classes, according to the five organs of the month
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employed in pronouncing them, namely, the lips, the tongue, the teeth, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: palate, and the throat. (98) For instance, Alpha, Ghet, Hgain, He, are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called gutturals, and are barely distinguishable, by any sign that we know,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one from the other. (99) El, which signifies to, is often taken for hgal,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which signifies above, and vice versa. (100) Hence sentences are often
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rendered rather ambiguous or meaningless.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (101) A second difficulty arises from the multiplied meaning of conjunctions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and adverbs. (102) For instance, vau serves promiscuously for a particle of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: union or of separation, meaning, and, but, because, however, then: ki, has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seven or eight meanings, namely, wherefore, although, if, when, inasmuch as,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because, a burning, &c., and so on with almost all particles.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (103) The third very fertile source of doubt is the fact that Hebrew verbs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the indicative mood lack the present, the past imperfect, the pluperfect,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the future perfect, and other tenses most frequently employed in other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: languages; in the imperative and infinitive moods they are wanting in all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except the present, and a subjunctive mood does not exist. (104) Now,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although all these defects in moods and tenses may be supplied by certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fundamental rules of the language with ease and even elegance, the ancient
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writers evidently neglected such rules altogether, and employed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indifferently future for present and past, and vice versa past for future,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and also indicative for imperative and subjunctive, with the result of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considerable confusion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (105) Besides these sources of ambiguity there are two others, one very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important. (106) Firstly, there are in Hebrew no vowels; secondly, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sentences are not separated by any marks elucidating the meaning or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: separating the clauses. (107) Though the want of these two has generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been supplied by points and accents, such substitutes cannot be accepted by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, inasmuch as they were invented and designed by men of an after age whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority should carry no weight. (108) The ancients wrote without points
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (that is, without vowels and accents), as is abundantly testified; their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: descendants added what was lacking, according to their own ideas of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural interpretation; wherefore the existing accents and points are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simply current interpretations, and are no more authoritative than any other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commentaries.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (109) Those who are ignorant of this fact cannot justify the author of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Epistle to the Hebrews for interpreting (chap. xi:21) Genesis (xlvii:31)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very differently from the version given in our Hebrew text as at present
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed, as though the Apostle had been obliged to learn the meaning of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture from those who added the points. (110) In my opinion the latter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are clearly wrong. (111) In order that everyone may judge for himself, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also see how the discrepancy arose simply from the want of vowels, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: give both interpretations. (112)Those who pointed our version read, "And
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israel bent himself over, or (changing Hqain into Aleph, a similar letter)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards, the head of the bed." (113) The author of the Epistle reads, "And
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israel bent himself over the head of his staff," substituting mate for mita,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from which it only differs in respect of vowels. (114) Now as in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative it is Jacob's age only that is in question, and not his illness,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is not touched on till the next chapter, it seems more likely that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian intended to say that Jacob bent over the head of his staff (a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing commonly used by men of advanced age for their support) than that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bowed himself at the head of his bed, especially as for the former reading
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no substitution of letters is required. (115) In this example I have desired
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not only to reconcile the passage in the Epistle with the passage in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Genesis, but also and chiefly to illustrate how little trust should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: placed in the points and accents which are found in our present Bible, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so to prove that he who would be without bias in interpreting Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should hesitate about accepting them, and inquire afresh for himself. (116)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such being the nature and structure of the Hebrew language, one may easily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand that many difficulties are likely to arise, and that no possible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: method could solve all of them. (117) It is useless to hope for a way out of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our difficulties in the comparison of various parallel passages (we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown that the only method of discovering the true sense of a passage out of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many alternative ones is to see what are the usages of the language), for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this comparison of parallel passages can only accidentally throw light on a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: difficult point, seeing that the prophets never wrote with the express
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of explaining their own phrases or those of other people, and also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because we cannot infer the meaning of one prophet or apostle by the meaning
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of another, unless on a purely practical question, not when the matter is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speculative, or if a miracle, or history is being narrated. (118) I might
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: illustrate my point with instances, for there are many inexplicable phrases
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Scripture, but I would rather pass on to consider the difficulties and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfections of the method under discussion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (119) A further difficulty attends the method, from the fact that it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requires the history of all that has happened to every book in the Bible;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a history we are often quite unable to furnish. (120) Of the authors,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or (if the expression be preferred), the writers of many of the books, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are either in complete ignorance, or at any rate in doubt, as I will point
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out at length. (121) Further, we do not know either the occasions or the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: epochs when these books of unknown authorship were written; we cannot say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into what hands they fell, nor how the numerous varying versions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: originated; nor, lastly, whether there were not other versions, now lost.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (122) I have briefly shown that such knowledge is necessary, but I passed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over certain considerations which I will now draw attention to.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (123) If we read a book which contains incredible or impossible narratives,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or is written in a very obscure style, and if we know nothing of its author,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor of the time or occasion of its being written, we shall vainly endeavour
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to gain any certain knowledge of its true meaning. (124) For being in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance on these points we cannot possibly know the aim or intended aim of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the author; if we are fully informed, we so order our thoughts as not to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in any way prejudiced either in ascribing to the author or him for whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: author wrote either more or less than his meaning, and we only take into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration what the author may have had in his mind, or what the time and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occasion demanded. (125) I think this must be tolerably evident to all.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (126) It often happens that in different books we read histories in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves similar, but which we judge very differently, according to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions we have formed of the authors. (127) I remember once to have read
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in some book that a man named Orlando Furioso used to drive a kind of winged
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: monster through the air, fly over any countries he liked, kill unaided vast
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: numbers of men and giants, and such like fancies, which from the point of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: view of reason are obviously absurd. (128) A very similar story I read in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ovid of Perseus, and also in the books of Judges and Kings of Samson, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone and unarmed killed thousands of men, and of Elijah, who flew through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the air, said at last went up to heaven in a chariot of fire, with horses of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fire. (129) All these stories are obviously alike, but we judge them very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differently. (130) The first only sought to amuse, the second had a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: political object, the third a religious object.(131) We gather this simply
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the opinions we had previously formed of the authors. (132) Thus it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is evidently necessary to know something of the authors of writings which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are obscure or unintelligible, if we would interpret their meaning; and for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same reason, in order to choose the proper reading from among a great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: variety, we ought to have information as to the versions in which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differences are found, and as to the possibility of other readings having
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been discovered by persons of greater authority.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (133) A further difficulty attends this method in the case of some of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books of Scripture, namely, that they are no longer extant in their original
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: language. (133) The Gospel according to Matthew, and certainly the Epistle
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the Hebrews, were written, it is thought, in Hebrew, though they no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer exist in that form. (134) Aben Ezra affirms in his commentaries that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the book of Job was translated into Hebrew out of another language, and that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its obscurity arises from this fact. (135) I say nothing of the apocryphal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books, for their authority stands on very inferior ground.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (136) The foregoing difficulties in this method of interpreting Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from its own history, I conceive to be so great that I do not hesitate to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say that the true meaning of Scripture is in many places inexplicable, or at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: best mere subject for guesswork; but I must again point out, on the other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, that such difficulties only arise when we endeavour to follow the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning of a prophet in matters which cannot be perceived, but only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagined, not in things, whereof the understanding can give a clear idea,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and which are conceivable through themselves:, [Endnote 8], matters which by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their nature are easily perceived cannot be expressed so obscurely as to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unintelligible; as the proverb says, "a word is enough to the wise." (137)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
