text: Euclid, who only wrote of matters very simple and easily understood, can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily be comprehended by anyone in any language; we can follow his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intention perfectly, and be certain of his true meaning, without having a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thorough knowledge of the language in which he wrote; in fact, a quite
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rudimentary acquaintance is sufficient. (138) We need make no researches
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the life, the pursuits, or the habits of the author; nor need we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inquire in what language, nor when he wrote, nor the vicissitudes of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book, nor its various readings, nor how, nor by whose advice it has been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: received.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (139) What we here say of Euclid might equally be said of any book which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treats of things by their nature perceptible: thus we conclude that we can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily follow the intention of Scripture in moral questions, from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history we possess of it, and we can be sure of its true meaning.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (140) The precepts of true piety are expressed in very ordinary language,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and are equally simple and easily understood. (141) Further, as true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: salvation and blessedness consist in a true assent of the soul - and we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truly assent only to what we clearly understand - it is most plain that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can follow with certainty the intention of Scripture in matters relating to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: salvation and necessary to blessedness; therefore, we need not be much
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: troubled about what remains: such matters, inasmuch as we generally cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grasp them with our reason and understanding, are more curious than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: profitable.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (142) I think I have now set forth the true method of Scriptural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpretation, and have sufficiently explained my own opinion thereon.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (143) Besides, I do not doubt that everyone will see that such a method only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requires the aid of natural reason. (144) The nature and efficacy of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural reason consists in deducing and proving the unknown from the known,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in carrying premises to their legitimate conclusions; and these are the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very processes which our method desiderates. (145) Though we must admit that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it does not suffice to explain everything in the Bible, such imperfection
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not spring from its own nature, but from the fact that the path
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it teaches us, as the true one, has never been tended or trodden by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men, and has thus, by the lapse of time, become very difficult, and almost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impassable, as, indeed, I have shown in the difficulties I draw attention
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (146) There only remains to examine the opinions of those who differ from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: me. (147) The first which comes under our notice is, that the light of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature has no power to interpret Scripture, but that a supernatural faculty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is required for the task. (148) What is meant by this supernatural faculty I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will leave to its propounders to explain. (149) Personally, I can only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suppose that they have adopted a very obscure way of stating their complete
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncertainty about the true meaning of Scripture. (150) If we look at their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpretations, they contain nothing supernatural, at least nothing but the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merest conjectures.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (151) Let them be placed side by side with the interpretations of those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frankly confess that they have no faculty beyond their natural ones; we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall see that the two are just alike - both human, both long pondered over,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: both laboriously invented. (152) To say that the natural reason is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insufficient for such results is plainly untrue, firstly, for the reasons
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above stated, namely, that the difficulty of interpreting Scripture arises
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from no defect in human reason, but simply from the carelessness (not to say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: malice) of men who neglected the history of the Bible while there were still
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: materials for inquiry; secondly, from the fact (admitted, I think, by all)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the supernatural faculty is a Divine gift granted only to the faithful.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (153) But the prophets and apostles did not preach to the faithful only, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chiefly to the unfaithful and wicked. (154) Such persons, therefore, were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: able to understand the intention of the prophets and apostles, otherwise the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets and apostles would have seemed to be preaching to little boys and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infants, not to men endowed with reason. (155) Moses, too, would have given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his laws in vain, if they could only be comprehended by the faithful, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need no law. (156) Indeed, those who demand supernatural faculties for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehending the meaning of the prophets and apostles seem truly lacking in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural faculties, so that we should hardly suppose such persons the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessors of a Divine supernatural gift.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (157) The opinion of Maimonides was widely different. (158) He asserted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that each passage in Scripture admits of various, nay, contrary,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meanings; but that we could never be certain of any particular one till we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knew that the passage, as we interpreted it, contained nothing contrary or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnant to reason. (159) If the literal meaning clashes with reason,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though the passage seems in itself perfectly clear, it must be interpreted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in some metaphorical sense. (160) This doctrine he lays down very plainly in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. xxv. part ii. of his book, "More Nebuchim," for he says: "Know that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shrink not from affirming that the world hath existed from eternity,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because of what Scripture saith concerning the world's creation. (161) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the texts which teach that the world was created are not more in number than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those which teach that God hath a body; neither are the approaches in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter of the world's creation closed, or even made hard to us: so that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should not be able to explain what is written, as we did when we showed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God hath no body, nay, peradventure, we could explain and make fast the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine of the world's eternity more easily than we did away with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrines that God hath a beatified body. (162) Yet two things hinder me
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from doing as I have said, and believing that the world is eternal.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (163) As it hath been clearly shown that God hath not a body, we must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perforce explain all those passages whereof the literal sense agreeth not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the demonstration, for sure it is that they can be so explained. (164)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But the eternity of the world hath not been so demonstrated, therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is not necessary to do violence to Scripture in support of some common
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinion, whereof we might, at the bidding of reason, embrace the contrary."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (165) Such are the words of Maimonides, and they are evidently sufficient to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: establish our point: for if he had been convinced by reason that the world
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is eternal, he would not have hesitated to twist and explain away the words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Scripture till he made them appear to teach this doctrine. (166) He would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have felt quite sure that Scripture, though everywhere plainly denying the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity of the world, really intends to teach it. (167) So that, however
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear the meaning of Scripture may be, he would not feel certain of having
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grasped it, so long as he remained doubtful of the truth of what, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written. (168) For we are in doubt whether a thing is in conformity with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, or contrary thereto, so long as we are uncertain of its truth,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, we cannot be sure whether the literal meaning of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passage be true or false.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (169) If such a theory as this were sound, I would certainly grant that some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty beyond the natural reason is required for interpreting Scripture.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (170) For nearly all things that we find in Scripture cannot be inferred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from known principles of the natural reason, and, therefore, we should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to come to any conclusion about their truth, or about the real
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning and intention of Scripture, but should stand in need of some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further assistance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (171) Further, the truth of this theory would involve that the masses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: having generally no comprehension of, nor leisure for, detailed proofs,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be reduced to receiving all their knowledge of Scripture on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority and testimony of philosophers, and, consequently, would be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled to suppose that the interpretations given by philosophers were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infallible.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (172) Truly this would be a new form of ecclesiastical authority, and a new
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sort of priests or pontiffs, more likely to excite men's ridicule than their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: veneration. (173) Certainly our method demands a knowledge of Hebrew for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the masses have no leisure; but no such objection as the foregoing can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be brought against us. (174) For the ordinary Jews or Gentiles, to whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets and apostles preached and wrote, understood the language, and,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, the intention of the prophet or apostle addressing them; but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they did not grasp the intrinsic reason of what was preached, which,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to Maimonides, would be necessary for an understanding of it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (175) There is nothing, then, in our method which renders it necessary that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the masses should follow the testimony of commentators, for I point to a set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of unlearned people who understood the language of the prophets and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apostles; whereas Maimonides could not point to any such who could arrive at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophetic or apostolic meaning through their knowledge of the causes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (176) As to the multitude of our own time, we have shown that whatsoever is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to salvation, though its reasons may be unknown, can easily be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood in any language, because it is thoroughly ordinary and usual; it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in such understanding as this that the masses acquiesce, not in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: testimony of commentators; with regard to other questions, the ignorant and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the learned fare alike.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (177) But let us return to the opinion of Maimonides, and examine it more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: closely. In the first place, he supposes that the prophets were in entire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agreement one with another, and that they were consummate philosophers and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theologians; for he would have them to have based their conclusions on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolute truth. (178) Further, he supposes that the sense of Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be made plain from Scripture itself, for the truth of things is not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made plain therein (in that it does not prove any thing, nor teach the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters of which it speaks through their definitions and first causes),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, according to Maimonides, the true sense of Scripture cannot be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made plain from itself, and must not be there sought.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (179) The falsity of such a doctrine is shown in this very chapter, for we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have shown both by reason and examples that the meaning of Scripture is only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made plain through Scripture itself, and even in questions deducible from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary knowledge should be looked for from no other source.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (180) Lastly, such a theory supposes that we may explain the words of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture according to our preconceived opinions, twisting them about, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reversing or completely changing the literal sense, however plain it may be.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (181) Such licence is utterly opposed to the teaching of this and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preceding chapters, and, moreover, will be evident to everyone as rash and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excessive.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (182) But if we grant all this licence, what can it effect after all?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Absolutely nothing. (183) Those things which cannot be demonstrated, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which make up the greater part of Scripture, cannot be examined by reason,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and cannot therefore be explained or interpreted by this rule; whereas,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the contrary, by following our own method, we can explain many questions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this nature, and discuss them on a sure basis, as we have already shown,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by reason and example. (184) Those matters which are by their nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehensible we can easily explain, as has been pointed out, simply by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means of the context.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (185) Therefore, the method of Maimonides is clearly useless: to which we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may add, that it does away with all the certainty which the masses acquire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by candid reading, or which is gained by any other persons in any other way.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (186) In conclusion, then, we dismiss Maimonides' theory as harmful,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useless, and absurd.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (187) As to the tradition of the Pharisees, we have already shown that it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not consistent, while the authority of the popes of Rome stands in need of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more credible evidence; the latter, indeed, I reject simply on this ground,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for if the popes could point out to us the meaning of Scripture as surely as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: did the high priests of the Jews, I should not be deterred by the fact that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there have been heretic and impious Roman pontiffs; for among the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high-priests of old there were also heretics and impious men who gained the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high- priesthood by improper means, but who, nevertheless, had Scriptural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sanction for their supreme power of interpreting the law. (See
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Deut. xvii:11, 12, and xxxiii:10, also Malachi ii:8.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (188) However, as the popes can show no such sanction, their authority
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remains open to very grave doubt, nor should anyone be deceived by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: example of the Jewish high-priests and think that the Catholic religion also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stands in need of a pontiff; he should bear in mind that the laws of Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being also the ordinary laws of the country, necessarily required some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public authority to insure their observance; for, if everyone were free to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpret the laws of his country as he pleased, no state could stand, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would for that very reason be dissolved at once, and public rights would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: become private rights.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (189) With religion the case is widely different. Inasmuch as it consists
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not so much in outward actions as in simplicity and truth of character, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stands outside the sphere of law and public authority. (190) Simplicity and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth of character are not produced by the constraint of laws, nor by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the authority of the state, no one the whole world over can be forced or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: legislated into a state of blessedness; the means required for such a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consummation are faithful and brotherly admonition, sound education, and,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above all, free use of the individual judgment.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (191) Therefore, as the supreme right of free thinking, even on religion, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in every man's power, and as it is inconceivable that such power could be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alienated, it is also in every man's power to wield the supreme right and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority of free judgment in this behalf, and to explain and interpret
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion for himself. (192) The only reason for vesting the supreme
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority in the interpretation of law, and judgment on public affairs in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the hands of the magistrates, is that it concerns questions of public right.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (193) Similarly the supreme authority in explaining religion, and in passing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment thereon, is lodged with the individual because it concerns
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: questions of individual right. (194) So far, then, from the authority of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrew high-priests telling in confirmation of the authority of the Roman
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pontiffs to interpret religion, it would rather tend to establish individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom of judgment. (195) Thus in this way also, we have shown that our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: method of interpreting Scripture is the best. (196) For as the highest power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Scriptural interpretation belongs to every man, the rule for such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpretation should be nothing but the natural light of reason which is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all - not any supernatural light nor any external authority;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moreover, such a rule ought not to be so difficult that it can only be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: applied by very skilful philosophers, but should be adapted to the natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and ordinary faculties and capacity of mankind. (197) And such I have shown
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our method to be, for such difficulties as it has arise from men's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carelessness, and are no part of its nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER VIII. - OF THE AUTHORSHIP OF THE PENTATEUCH AND THE OTHER
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: HISTORICAL BOOKS OF THE OLD TESTAMENT
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) In the former chapter we treated of the foundations and principles of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural knowledge, and showed that it consists solely in a trustworthy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history of the sacred writings; such a history, in spite of its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indispensability, the ancients neglected, or at any rate, whatever they may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have written or handed down has perished in the lapse of time, consequently
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the groundwork for such an investigation is to a great extent, cut from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under us. (2) This might be put up with if succeeding generations had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confined themselves within the limits of truth, and had handed down
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conscientiously what few particulars they had received or discovered without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any additions from their own brains: as it is, the history of the Bible is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not so much imperfect as untrustworthy: the foundations are not only too
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scanty for building upon, but are also unsound. (3) It is part of my purpose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to remedy these defects, and to remove common theological prejudices. (4)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But I fear that I am attempting my task too late, for men have arrived at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the pitch of not suffering contradiction, but defending obstinately whatever
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have adopted under the name of religion. (5) So widely have these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prejudices taken possession of men's minds, that very few, comparatively
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking, will listen to reason. (6) However, I will make the attempt, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spare no efforts, for there is no positive reason for despairing of success.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) In order to treat the subject methodically, I will begin with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: received opinions concerning the true authors of the sacred books, and in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the first place, speak of the author of the Pentateuch, who is almost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universally supposed to have been Moses. (8) The Pharisees are so firmly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convinced of his identity, that they account as a heretic anyone who differs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from them on the subject. (9) Wherefore, Aben Ezra, a man of enlightened
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intelligence, and no small learning, who was the first, so far as I know,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to treat of this opinion, dared not express his meaning openly, but confined
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself to dark hints which I shall not scruple to elucidate, thus throwing,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: full light on the subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (10) The words of Aben Ezra which occur in his commentary on Deuteronomy are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as follows: "Beyond Jordan, &c . . . If so be that thou understandest the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mystery of the twelve . . .  moreover Moses wrote the law . . .  The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Canaanite was then in the land . . . . it shall be revealed on the mount of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God . . . . then also behold his bed, his iron bed, then shalt thou know
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the truth." (11) In these few words he hints, and also shows that it was not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses who wrote the Pentateuch, but someone who lived long after him, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, that the book which Moses wrote was something different from any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now extant.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) To prove this, I say, he draws attention to the facts:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) 1. That the preface to Deuteronomy could not have been written by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, inasmuch as he ad never crossed the Jordan.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (14) II. That the whole book of Moses was written at full length on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumference of a single altar (Deut. xxvii, and Josh. viii:37), which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: altar, according to the Rabbis, consisted of only twelve stones: therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the book of Moses must have been of far less extent than the Pentateuch.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (15) This is what our author means, I think, by the mystery of the twelve,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless he is referring to the twelve curses contained in the chapter of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Deuteronomy above cited, which he thought could not have been contained in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the law, because Moses bade the Levites read them after the recital of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law, and so bind the people to its observance. (16) Or again, he may have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had in his mind the last chapter of Deuteronomy which treats of the death of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, and which contains twelve verses. (17) But there is no need to dwell
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further on these and similar conjectures.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18) III. That in Deut. xxxi:9, the expression occurs, "and Moses wrote the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law:" words that cannot be ascribed to Moses, but must be those of some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other writer narrating the deeds and writings of Moses.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19) IV. That in Genesis xii:6, the historian, after narrating that Abraham
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: journeyed through the and of Canaan, adds, "and the Canaanite was then in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the land," thus clearly excluding the time at which he wrote. (20) So that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this passage must have been written after the death of Moses, when the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Canaanites had been driven out, and no longer possessed the land.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) Aben Ezra, in his commentary on the passage, alludes to the difficulty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as follows:- "And the Canaanite was then in the land: it appears that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Canaan, the grandson of Noah, took from another the land which bears his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name; if this be not the true meaning, there lurks some mystery in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passage, and let him who understands it keep silence." (22) That is, if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Canaan invaded those regions, the sense will be, the Canaanite was then in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the land, in contradistinction to the time when it had been held by another:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but if, as follows from Gen. chap. x. Canaan was the first to inhabit the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: land, the text must mean to exclude the time present, that is the time at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it was written; therefore it cannot be the work of Moses, in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whose time the Canaanites still possessed those territories: this is the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mystery concerning which silence is recommended.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (23) V. That in Genesis xxii:14 Mount Moriah is called the mount of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 9], a name which it did not acquire till after the building of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Temple; the choice of the mountain was not made in the time of Moses, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses does not point out any spot as chosen by God; on the contrary, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foretells that God will at some future time choose a spot to which this name
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be given.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) VI. Lastly, that in Deut. chap. iii., in the passage relating to Og,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king of Bashan, these words are inserted: "For only Og king of Bashan
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remained of the remnant of giants: behold, his bedstead was a bedstead of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iron: is it not in Rabbath of the children of Ammon? nine cubits was the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: length thereof, and four cubits the breadth of it, after the cubit of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man." (25) This parenthesis most plainly shows that its writer lived long
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after Moses; for this mode of speaking is only employed by one treating of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things long past, and pointing to relics for the sake of gaining credence:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moreover, this bed was almost certainly first discovered by David, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conquered the city of Rabbath (2 Sam. xii:30.) (26) Again, the historian a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: little further on inserts after the words of Moses, "Jair, the son of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Manasseh, took all the country of Argob unto the coasts of Geshuri and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Maachathi; and called them after his own name, Bashan-havoth-jair, unto this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day." (27) This passage, I say, is inserted to explain the words of Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which precede it. (28) "And the rest of Gilead, and all Bashan, being the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kingdom of Og, gave I unto the half tribe of Manasseh; all the region of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Argob, with all Bashan, which is called the land of the giants." (29) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrews in the time of the writer indisputably knew what territories
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belonged to the tribe of Judah, but did not know them under the name of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: jurisdiction of Argob, or the land of the giants. (30) Therefore the writer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is compelled to explain what these places were which were anciently so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: styled, and at the same time to point out why they were at the time of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writing known by the name of Jair, who was of the tribe of Manasseh, not of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judah. (31) We have thus made clear the meaning of Aben Ezra and also the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages of the Pentateuch which he cites in proof of his contention. (32)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, Aben Ezra does not call attention to every instance, or even the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chief ones; there remain many of greater importance, which may be cited.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (33) Namely (I.), that the writer of the books in question not only speaks
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Moses in the third person, but also bears witness to many details
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning him; for instance, "Moses talked with God;" "The Lord spoke with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses face to face;" "Moses was the meekest of men" (Numb. xii:3); "Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was wrath with the captains of the host; "Moses, the man of God, "Moses, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: servant of the Lord, died;" "There was never a prophet in Israel like
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unto Moses," &c. (34) On the other hand, in Deuteronomy, where the law which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses had expounded to the people and written is set forth, Moses speaks and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: declares what he has done in the first person: "God spake with me" (Deut.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii:1, 17, &c.), "I prayed to the Lord," &c. (35) Except at the end of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book, when the historian, after relating the words of Moses, begins again to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speak in the third person, and to tell how Moses handed over the law which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he had expounded to the people in writing, again admonishing them, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, how Moses ended his life. (36) All these details, the manner of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narration, the testimony, and the context of the whole story lead to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain conclusion that these books were written by another, and not by Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in person.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (37) III. We must also remark that the history relates not only the manner
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Moses' death and burial, and the thirty days' mourning of the Hebrews,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but further compares him with all the prophets who came after him, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states that he surpassed them all. (38) "There was never a prophet in Israel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like unto Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face." (39) Such testimony
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot have been given of Moses by, himself, nor by any who immediately
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: succeeded him, but it must come from someone who lived centuries afterwards,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially, as the historian speaks of past times. (40) "There was never a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet," &c. (41) And of the place of burial, "No one knows it to this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) III. We must note that some places are not styled by the names they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bore during Moses' lifetime, but by others which they obtained subsequently.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (43) For instance, Abraham is said to have pursued his enemies even unto
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Dan, a name not bestowed on the city till long after the death of Joshua
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Gen. xiv:14, Judges xviii:29).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (44) IV. The narrative is prolonged after the death of Moses, for in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Exodus xvi:34 we read that "the children of Israel did eat manna forty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years until they came to a land inhabited, until they came unto the borders
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the land of Canaan." (45) In other words, until the time alluded to in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua vi:12.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (46) So, too, in Genesis xxxvi:31 it is stated, "These are the kings that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reigned in Edom before there reigned any king over the children of Israel."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (47) The historian, doubtless, here relates the kings of Idumaea before that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: territory was conquered by David [Endnote 10] and garrisoned, as we read
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in 2 Sam. viii:14. (48) From what has been said, it is thus clearer than the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sun at noonday that the Pentateuch was not written by Moses, but by someone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who lived long after Moses. (49) Let us now turn our attention to the books
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which Moses actually did write, and which are cited in the Pentateuch; thus,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also, shall we see that they were different from the Pentateuch. (50)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Firstly, it appears from Exodus xvii:14 that Moses, by the command of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wrote an account of the war against Amalek. (51) The book in which he did so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not named in the chapter just quoted, but in Numb. xxi:12 a book is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to under the title of the wars of God, and doubtless this war
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against Amalek and the castrametations said in Numb. xxxiii:2 to have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written by Moses are therein described. (52) We hear also in Exod. xxiv:4 of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another book called the Book of the Covenant, which Moses read before the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israelites when they first made a covenant with God. (53) But this book or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this writing contained very little, namely, the laws or commandments of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we find in Exodus xx:22 to the end of chap. xxiv., and this no one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will deny who reads the aforesaid chapter rationally and impartially. (54)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is there stated that as soon as Moses had learnt the feeling of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people on the subject of making a covenant with God, he immediately wrote
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down God's laws and utterances, and in the morning, after some ceremonies
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had been performed, read out the conditions of the covenant to an assembly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the whole people. (55) When these had been gone through, and doubtless
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood by all, the whole people gave their assent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (56) Now from the shortness of the time taken in its perusal and also from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its nature as a compact, this document evidently contained nothing more than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which we have just described. (57) Further, it is clear that Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained all the laws which he had received in the fortieth year after the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exodus from Egypt; also that he bound over the people a second time to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observe them, and that finally he committed them to writing (Deut. i:5;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix:14; xxxi:9), in a book which contained these laws explained, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: new covenant, and this book was therefore called the book of the law of God:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same which was afterwards added to by Joshua when he set forth the fresh
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covenant with which he bound over the people and which he entered into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with God (Josh. xxiv:25, 26).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (58) Now, as we have extent no book containing this covenant of Moses and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also the covenant of Joshua, we must perforce conclude that it has perished,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless, indeed, we adopt the wild conjecture of the Chaldean paraphrast
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jonathan, and twist about the words of Scripture to our heart's content.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (59) This commentator, in the face of our present difficulty, preferred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corrupting the sacred text to confessing his own ignorance. (60) The passage
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the book of Joshua which runs, "and Joshua wrote these words in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book of the law of God," he changes into "and Joshua wrote these words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and kept them with the book of the law of God." (61) What is to be done with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persons who will only see what pleases them? (62) What is such a proceeding
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if it is not denying Scripture, and inventing another Bible out of our own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heads? (63) We may therefore conclude that the book of the law of God which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses wrote was not the Pentateuch, but something quite different, which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: author of the Pentateuch duly inserted into his book. (64) So much is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abundantly plain both from what I have said and from what I am about to add.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) For in the passage of Deuteronomy above quoted, where it is related
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Moses wrote the book of the law, the historian adds that he handed it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over to the priests and bade them read it out at a stated time to the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people. (66) This shows that the work was of much less length than the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pentateuch, inasmuch as it could be read through at one sitting so as to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood by all; further, we must not omit to notice that out of all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books which Moses wrote, this one book of the second covenant and the song
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (which latter he wrote afterwards so that all the people might learn it),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was the only one which he caused to be religiously guarded and preserved.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (67) In the first covenant he had only bound over those who were present,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but in the second covenant he bound over all their descendants also (Dent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix:14), and therefore ordered this covenant with future ages to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religiously preserved, together with the Song, which was especially
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: addressed to posterity: as, then, we have no proof that Moses wrote any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book save this of the covenant, and as he committed no other to the care of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: posterity; and, lastly, as there are many passages in the Pentateuch which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses could not have written, it follows that the belief that Moses was the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: author of the Pentateuch is ungrounded and even irrational. (68) Someone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will perhaps ask whether Moses did not also write down other laws when they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were first revealed to him - in other words, whether, during the course of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forty years, he did not write down any of the laws which he promulgated,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save only those few which I have stated to be contained in the book of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first covenant. (69) To this I would answer, that although it seems
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasonable to suppose that Moses wrote down the laws at the time when he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished to communicate them to the people, yet we are not warranted to take
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it as proved, for I have shown above that we must make no assertions in such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters which we do not gather from Scripture, or which do not flow as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: legitimate consequences from its fundamental principles. (70) We must not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accept whatever is reasonably probable. (71) However even reason in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case would not force such a conclusion upon us: for it may be that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assembly of elders wrote down the decrees of Moses and communicated them to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the people, and the historian collected them, and duly set them forth in his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative of the life of Moses. (72) So much for the five books of Moses: it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is now time for us to turn to the other sacred writings.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (73) The book of Joshua may be proved not to be an autograph by reasons
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar to those we have just employed: for it must be some other than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua who testifies that the fame of Joshua was spread over the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: world; that he omitted nothing of what Moses had taught (Josh. vi:27; viii.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last verse; xi:15); that he grew old and summoned an assembly of the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, and finally that he departed this life. (74) Furthermore, events are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: related which took place after Joshua's death. (75) For instance, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israelites worshipped God, after his death, so long as there were any old
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men alive who remembered him; and in chap. xvi:10, we read that "Ephraim and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Manasseh did not drive out the Canaanites which dwelt in Gezer, but the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Canaanite dwelt in the land of Ephraim unto this day, and was tributary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him." (76) This is the same statement as that in Judges, chap. i., and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phrase "unto this day" shows that the writer was speaking of ancient times.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (77) With these texts we may compare the last verse of chap. xv., concerning
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sons of Judah, and also the history of Caleb in the same chap. v:14.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (78) Further, the building of an altar beyond Jordan by the two tribes and a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: half, chap. xxii:10, sqq., seems to have taken place after the death of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua, for in the whole narrative his name is never mentioned, but the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people alone held council as to waging war, sent out legates, waited for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their return, and finally approved of their answer.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (79) Lastly, from chap. x:14, it is clear that the book was written many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generations after the death of Joshua, for it bears witness, there was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never any, day like unto, that day, either before or after, that the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hearkened to the voice of a man," &c. (80) If, therefore, Joshua wrote any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book at all, it was that which is quoted in the work now before us,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. x:13.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) With regard to the book of Judges, I suppose no rational person
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuades himself that it was written by the actual Judges. (82) For the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion of the whole history contained in chap. ii. clearly shows that it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is all the work - of a single historian. (83) Further, inasmuch as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writer frequently tells us that there was then no king in Israel, it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident that the book was written after the establishment of the monarchy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (84) The books of Samuel need not detain us long, inasmuch as the narrative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in them is continued long after Samuel's death; but I should like to draw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attention to the fact that it was written many generations after Samuel's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: death. (85) For in book i. chap. ix:9, the historian remarks in a,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parenthesis, "Beforetime, in Israel, when a man went to inquire of God, thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he spake: Come, and let us go to the seer; for he that is now called a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet was beforetime called a seer."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (86) Lastly, the books of Kings, as we gather from internal evidence, were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compiled from the books of King Solomon (I Kings xi:41), from the chronicles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the kings of Judah (1 Kings xiv:19, 29), and the chronicles of the kings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Israel.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (87) We may, therefore, conclude that all the books we have considered
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hitherto are compilations, and that the events therein are recorded as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: having happened in old time. (88) Now, if we turn our attention to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: connection and argument of all these books, we shall easily see that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were all written by a single historian, who wished to relate the antiquities
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Jews from their first beginning down to the first destruction of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: city. (89) The way in which the several books are connected one with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other is alone enough to show us that they form the narrative of one and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same writer. (90) For as soon as he has related the life of Moses, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian thus passes on to the story of Joshua: "And it came to pass after
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Moses the servant of the Lord was dead, that God spake unto Joshua,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c., so in the same way, after the death of Joshua was concluded, he passes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with identically the same transition and connection to the history of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judges: "And it came to pass after that Joshua was dead, that the children
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Israel sought from God," &c. (91) To the book of Judges he adds the story
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Ruth, as a sort of appendix, in these words: "Now it came to pass in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: days that the judges ruled, that there was a famine in the land."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (92) The first book of Samuel is introduced with a similar phrase; and so is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the second book of Samuel. (93) Then, before the history of David is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concluded, the historian passes in the same way to the first book of Kings,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, after David's death, to the Second book of Kings.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) The putting together, and the order of the narratives, show that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are all the work of one man, writing with a create aim; for the historian
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: begins with relating the first origin of the Hebrew nation, and then sets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth in order the times and the occasions in which Moses put forth his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws, and made his predictions. (95) He then proceeds to relate how the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israelites invaded the promised land in accordance with Moses' prophecy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
