text: (Deut. vii.); and how, when the land was subdued, they turned their backs on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their laws, and thereby incurred many misfortunes (Deut. xxxi:16, 17). (96)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He tells how they wished to elect rulers, and how, according as these rulers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observed the law, the people flourished or suffered (Deut. xxviii:36);
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finally, how destruction came upon the nation, even as Moses had foretold.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (97) In regard to other matters, which do not serve to confirm the law, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writer either passes over them in silence, or refers the reader to other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books for information. (98) All that is set down in the books we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduces to the sole object of setting forth the words and laws of Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and proving them by subsequent events.(99) When we put together these three
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considerations, namely, the unity of the subject of all the books, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: connection between them, and the fact that they are compilations made many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generations after the events they relate had taken place, we come to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion, as I have just stated, that they are all the work of a single
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian. (100) Who this historian was, it is not so easy to show; but I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspect that he was Ezra, and there are several strong reasons for adopting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this hypothesis.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (101) The historian whom we already know to be but one individual brings his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history down to the liberation of Jehoiakim, and adds that he himself sat at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the king's table all his life - that is, at the table either of Jehoiakim,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or of the son of Nebuchadnezzar, for the sense of the passage is ambiguous:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence it follows that he did not live before the time of Ezra. (102) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture does not testify of any except of Ezra (Ezra vii:10), that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "prepared his heart to seek the law of the Lord, and to set it forth, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further that he was a ready scribe in the law of Moses." (103) Therefore, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can not find anyone, save Ezra, to whom to attribute the sacred books.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) Further, from this testimony concerning Ezra, we see that he prepared
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his heart, not only to seek the law of the Lord, but also to set it forth;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, in Nehemiah viii:8, we read that "they read in the book of the law of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God distinctly, and gave the sense, and caused them to understand the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reading."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (105) As, then, in Deuteronomy, we find not only the book of the law of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, or the greater part of it, but also many things inserted for its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: better explanation, I conjecture that this Deuteronomy is the book of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law of God, written, set forth, and explained by Ezra, which is referred to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the text above quoted. (106) Two examples of the way matters were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inserted parenthetically in the text of Deuteronomy, with a view to its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fuller explanation, we have already given, in speaking of Aben Ezra's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinion. (107) Many others are found in the course of the work: for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, in chap. ii:12: "The Horims dwelt also in Seir beforetime; but the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children of Esau succeeded them, when they had destroyed them from before
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, and dwelt in their stead; as Israel did unto the land of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possession, which the Lord gave unto them." (108) This explains verses 3 and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 4 of the same chapter, where it is stated that Mount Seir, which had come to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the children of Esau for a possession, did not fall into their hands
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uninhabited; but that they invaded it, and turned out and destroyed the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Horims, who formerly dwelt therein, even as the children of Israel had done
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unto the Canaanites after the death of Moses.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (109) So, also, verses 6, 7, 8, 9, of the tenth chapter are inserted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parenthetically among the words of Moses. Everyone must see that verse 8,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which begins, "At that time the Lord separated the tribe of Levi,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily refers to verse 5, and not to the death of Aaron, which is only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mentioned here by Ezra because Moses, in telling of the golden calf
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worshipped by the people, stated that he had prayed for Aaron.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (110) He then explains that at the time at which Moses spoke, God had chosen
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for Himself the tribe of Levi in order that He may point out the reason for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their election, and for the fact of their not sharing in the inheritance;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after this digression, he resumes the thread of Moses' speech. (111) To
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these parentheses we must add the preface to the book, and all the passages
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in which Moses is spoken of in the third person, besides many which we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot now distinguish, though, doubtless, they would have been plainly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recognized by the writer's contemporaries.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (112) If, I say, we were in possession of the book of the law as Moses wrote
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, I do not doubt that we should find a great difference in the words of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the precepts, the order in which they are given, and the reasons by which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are supported.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (113) A comparison of the decalogue in Deuteronomy with the decalogue in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Exodus, where its history is explicitly set forth, will be sufficient to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show us a wide discrepancy in all these three particulars, for the fourth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commandment is given not only in a different form, but at much greater
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: length, while the reason for its observance differs wholly from that stated
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Exodus. (114) Again, the order in which the tenth commandment is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained differs in the two versions. (115) I think that the differences
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here as elsewhere are the work of Ezra, who explained the law of God to his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemporaries, and who wrote this book of the law of God, before anything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else; this I gather from the fact that it contains the laws of the country,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of which the people stood in most need, and also because it is not joined to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the book which precedes it by any connecting phrase, but begins with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: independent statement, "these are the words of Moses." (116) After this task
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was completed, I think Ezra set himself to give a complete account of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history of the Hebrew nation from the creation of the world to the entire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destruction of the city, and in this account he inserted the book of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Deuteronomy, and, possibly, he called the first five books by the name of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, because his life is chiefly contained therein, and forms their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principal subject; for the same reason he called the sixth Joshua, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seventh Judges, the eighth Ruth, the ninth, and perhaps the tenth, Samuel,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, lastly, the eleventh and twelfth Kings. (117) Whether Ezra put the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finishing touches to this work and finished it as he intended, we will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discuss in the next chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER IX - OTHER QUESTIONS CONCERNING THE SAME BOOKS: NAMELY, WHETHER THEY
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: WERE COMPLETELY FINISHED BY EZRA, AND, FURTHER, WHETHER THE MARGINAL
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: NOTES WHICH ARE FOUND IN THE HEBREW TEXTS WERE VARIOUS READINGS.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) How greatly the inquiry we have just made concerning the real writer of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the twelve books aids us in attaining a complete understanding of them, may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be easily gathered solely from the passages which we have adduced in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confirmation of our opinion, and which would be most obscure without it. (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But besides the question of the writer, there are other points to notice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which common superstition forbids the multitude to apprehend. (3) Of these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chief is, that Ezra (whom I will take to be the author of the aforesaid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books until some more likely person be suggested) did not put the finishing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: touches to the narrative contained therein, but merely collected the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: histories from various writers, and sometimes simply set them down, leaving
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their examination and arrangement to posterity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (4) The cause (if it were not untimely death) which prevented him from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: completing his work in all its portions, I cannot conjecture, but the fact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remains most clear, although we have lost the writings of the ancient Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historians, and can only judge from the few fragments which are still
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extant. (5) For the history of Hezekiah (2 Kings xviii:17), as written in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the vision of Isaiah, is related as it is found in the chronicles of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kings of Judah. (6) We read the same story, told with few exceptions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 11], in the same words, in the book of Isaiah which was contained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the chronicles of the kings of Judah (2 Chron. xxxii:32). (7) From this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we must conclude that there were various versions of this narrative of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isaiah's, unless, indeed, anyone would dream that in this, too, there lurks
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a mystery. (8) Further, the last chapter of 2 Kings 27-30 is repeated in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last chapter of Jeremiah, v.31-34.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) Again, we find 2 Sam. vii. repeated in I Chron. xvii., but the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expressions in the two passages are so curiously varied [Endnote 12], that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we can very easily see that these two chapters were taken from two different
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: versions of the history of Nathan.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (10) Lastly, the genealogy of the kings of Idumaea contained in Genesis
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvi:31, is repeated in the same words in 1 Chron. i., though we know that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the author of the latter work took his materials from other historians, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the twelve books we have ascribed to Ezra. (10) We may therefore be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sure that if we still possessed the writings of the historians, the matter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be made clear; however, as we have lost them, we can only examine the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writings still extant, and from their order and connection, their various
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repetitions, and, lastly, the contradictions in dates which they contain,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judge of the rest.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (11) These, then, or the chief of them, we will now go through. (12) First,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the story of Judah and Tamar (Gen. xxxviii.) the historian thus begins:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "And it came to pass at that time that Judah went down from his brethren."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) This time cannot refer to what immediately precedes [Endnote 13], but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must necessarily refer to something else, for from the time when Joseph was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sold into Egypt to the time when the patriarch Jacob, with all his family,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set out thither, cannot be reckoned as more than twenty-two years, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joseph, when he was sold by his brethren, was seventeen years old, and when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he was summoned by Pharaoh from prison was thirty; if to this we add the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seven years of plenty and two of famine, the total amounts to twenty-two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years. (14) Now, in so short a period, no one can suppose that so many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things happened as are described; that Judah had three children, one after
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other, from one wife, whom he married at the beginning of the period;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the eldest of these, when he was old enough, married Tamar, and that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after he died his next brother succeeded to her; that, after all this,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judah, without knowing it, had intercourse with his daughter-in-law, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that she bore him twins, and, finally, that the eldest of these twins became
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a father within the aforesaid period. (15) As all these events cannot have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: taken place within the period mentioned in Genesis, the reference must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily be to something treated of in another book: and Ezra in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance simply related the story, and inserted it without examination among
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his other writings.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16) However, not only this chapter but the whole narrative of Joseph and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jacob is collected and set forth from various histories, inasmuch as it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quite inconsistent with itself. (17) For in Gen. xlvii. we are told that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jacob, when he came at Joseph's bidding to salute Pharaoh, was 130 years
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: old. (18) If from this we deduct the twenty-two years which he passed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sorrowing for the absence of Joseph and the seventeen years forming Joseph's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: age when he was sold, and, lastly, the seven years for which Jacob served
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for Rachel, we find that he was very advanced in life, namely, eighty four,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he took Leah to wife, whereas Dinah was scarcely seven years old when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: she was violated by Shechem, [Endnote 14]. (19) Simeon and Levi were aged
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respectively eleven and twelve when they spoiled the city and slew all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: males therein with the sword.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20) There is no need that I should go through the whole Pentateuch. (21) If
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone pays attention to the way in which all the histories and precepts in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these five books are set down promiscuously and without order, with no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard for dates; and further, how the same story is often repeated,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes in a different version, he will easily, I say, discern that all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the materials were promiscuously collected and heaped together, in order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they might at some subsequent time be more readily examined and reduced
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to order. (22) Not only these five books, but also the narratives contained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the remaining seven, going down to the destruction of the city, are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compiled in the same way. (23) For who does not see that in Judges ii:6 a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: new historian is being quoted, who had also written of the deeds of Joshua,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that his words are simply copied? (24) For after our historian has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stated in the last chapter of the book of Joshua that Joshua died and was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: buried, and has promised, in the first chapter of Judges, to relate what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happened after his death, in what way, if he wished to continue the thread
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his history, could he connect the statement here made about Joshua with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what had gone before?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (25) So, too, 1 Sam. 17, 18, are taken from another historian, who assigns a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause for David's first frequenting Saul's court very different from that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given in chap. xvi. of the same book. (26) For he did not think that David
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: came to Saul in consequence of the advice of Saul's servants, as is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrated in chap. xvi., but that being sent by chance to the camp by his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: father on a message to his brothers, he was for the first time remarked by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Saul on the occasion of his victory, over Goliath the Philistine, and was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retained at his court.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (27) I suspect the same thing has taken place in chap. xxvi. of the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book, for the historian there seems to repeat the narrative given in chap.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiv. according to another man's version. (28) But I pass over this, and go
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on to the computation of dates.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (29) In I Kings, chap. vi., it is said that Solomon built the Temple in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: four hundred and eightieth year after the exodus from Egypt; but from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historians themselves we get a much longer period, for:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Years.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses governed the people in the desert . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 40
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua, who lived 110 years, did not, according to Josephus and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others' opinion rule more than  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 26
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Cusban Rishathaim held the people in subjection . . . . . . . . . . .  8
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Othniel, son of Kenag, was judge for  . . . . . . . . .  [Endnote 15] 40
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Eglon, King of Moab, governed the people  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 18
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ehud and Shamgar were judges  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 80
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jachin, King of Canaan, held the people in subjection . . . . . . . . 20
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The people was at peace subsequently for  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 40
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It was under subjection to Median . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  7
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It obtained freedom under Gideon for  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 40
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It fell under the rule of Abimelech . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  3
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Tola, son of Puah, was judge  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 23
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The people was in subjection to the Philistines and Ammonites . . . . 18
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ibzan, the Bethlehemite, was judge  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  7
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Abclon, the Pirathonite . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  8
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The people was again subject to the Philistines . . . . . . . . . . . 40
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Samson was judge  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  [Endnote 16] 20
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The people again fell into subjection to the Philistines,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: till they were delivered by Samuel .  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 20
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Solomon reigned before he built the temple  . . . . . . . . . . . . .  4
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) All these periods added together make a total of 580 years. (31) But to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these must be added the years during which the Hebrew republic flourished
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after the death of Joshua, until it was conquered by Cushan Rishathaim,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which I take to be very numerous, for I cannot bring myself to believe that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: immediately after the death of Joshua all those who had witnessed his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles died simultaneously, nor that their successors at one stroke bid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: farewell to their laws, and plunged from the highest virtue into the depth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of wickedness and obstinacy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) Nor, lastly, that Cushan Rishathaim subdued them on the instant; each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one of these circumstances requires almost a generation, and there is no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt that Judges ii:7, 9, 10, comprehends a great many years which it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passes over in silence. (33) We must also add the years during which Samuel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was judge, the number of which is not stated in Scripture, and also the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years during which Saul reigned, which are not clearly shown from his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history. (34) It is, indeed, stated in 1 Sam. xiii:1, that he reigned two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years, but the text in that passage is mutilated, and the records of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign lead us to suppose a longer period. (35) That the text is mutilated I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suppose no one will doubt who has ever advanced so far as the threshold of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Hebrew language, for it runs as follows: "Saul was in his -- year, when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he began to reign, and he reigned two years over Israel." (36) Who, I say,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not see that the number of the years of Saul's age when he began to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign has been omitted? (37) That the record of the reign presupposes a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater number of years is equally beyond doubt, for in the same book, chap.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvii:7, it is stated that David sojourned among the Philistines, to whom he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had fled on account of Saul, a year and four months; thus the rest of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign must have been comprised in a space of eight months, which I think
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no one will credit. (38) Josephus, at the end of the sixth book of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: antiquities, thus corrects the text: Saul reigned eighteen years while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Samuel was alive, and two years after his death. (39) However, all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative in chap. xiii. is in complete disagreement with what goes before.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) At the end of chap. vii. it is narrated that the Philistines were so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: crushed by the Hebrews that they did not venture, during Samuel's life, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: invade the borders of Israel; but in chap. xiii. we are told that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrews were invaded during the life of Samuel by the Philistines, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reduced by them to such a state of wretchedness and poverty that they were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deprived not only of weapons with which to defend themselves, but also of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the means of making more. (41) I should be at pains enough if I were to try
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and harmonize all the narratives contained in this first book of Samuel so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they should seem to be all written and arranged by a single historian.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) But I return to my object. (43) The years, then, during which Saul
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reigned must be added to the above computation; and, lastly, I have not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counted the years of the Hebrew anarchy, for I cannot from Scripture gather
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their number. (44) I cannot, I say, be certain as to the period occupied by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the events related in Judges chap. xvii. on till the end of the book.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) It is thus abundantly evident that we cannot arrive at a true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: computation of years from the histories, and, further, that the histories
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are inconsistent themselves on the subject. (46) We are compelled to confess
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that these histories were compiled from various writers without previous
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arrangement and examination. (47) Not less discrepancy is found between the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dates given in the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, and those in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Chronicles of the Kings of Israel; in the latter, it is stated that Jehoram,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the son of Ahab, began to reign in the second year of the reign of Jehoram,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the son of Jehoshaphat (2 Kings i:17), but in the former we read that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jehoram, the son of Jehoshaphat, began to reign in the fifth year of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jehoram, the son of Ahab (2 Kings viii:16). (48) Anyone who compares the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narratives in Chronicles with the narratives in the books of Kings, will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find many similar discrepancies. (49) These there is no need for me to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: examine here, and still less am I called upon to treat of the commentaries
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of those who endeavour to harmonize them. (50) The Rabbis evidently let their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fancy run wild. (51) Such commentators as I have, read, dream, invent, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as a last resort, play fast and loose with the language. (52) For instance,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when it is said in 2 Chronicles, that Ahab was forty-two years old when he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: began to reign, they pretend that these years are computed from the reign of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Omri, not from the birth of Ahab. (53) If this can be shown to be the real
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning of the writer of the book of Chronicles, all I can say is, that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: did not know how to state a fact. (54) The commentators make many other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assertions of this kind, which if true, would prove that the ancient Hebrews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were ignorant both of their own language, and of the way to relate a plain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative. (55) I should in such case recognize no rule or reason in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreting Scripture, but it would be permissible to hypothesize to one's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heart's content.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (56) If anyone thinks that I am speaking too generally, and without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sufficient warrant, I would ask him to set himself to showing us some fixed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plan in these histories which might be followed without blame by other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writers of chronicles, and in his efforts at harmonizing and interpretation,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so strictly to observe and explain the phrases and expressions, the order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the connections, that we may be able to imitate these also in our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writings (17). (57) If he succeeds, I will at once give him my hand, and he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall be to me as great Apollo; for I confess that after long endeavours I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been unable to discover anything of the kind. (58) I may add that I set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down nothing here which I have not long reflected upon, and that, though I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was imbued from my boyhood up with the ordinary opinions about the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptures, I have been unable to withstand the force of what I have urged.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (59) However, there is no need to detain the reader with this question, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drive him to attempt an impossible task; I merely mentioned the fact in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order to throw light on my intention.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) I now pass on to other points concerning the treatment of these books.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (61) For we must remark, in addition to what has been shown, that these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books were not guarded by posterity with such care that no faults crept in.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (62) The ancient scribes draw attention to many doubtful readings, and some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutilated passages, but not to all that exist: whether the faults are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of sufficient importance to greatly embarrass the reader I will not now
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discuss. (63) I am inclined to think that they are of minor moment to those,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at any rate, who read the Scriptures with enlightenment: and I can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positively, affirm that I have not noticed any fault or various reading in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrinal passages sufficient to render them obscure or doubtful.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (64) There are some people, however, who will not admit that there is any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corruption, even in other passages, but maintain that by some unique
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exercise of providence God has preserved from corruption every word in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bible: they say that the various readings are the symbols of profoundest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mysteries, and that mighty secrets lie hid in the twenty-eight hiatus which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occur, nay, even in the very form of the letters.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) Whether they are actuated by folly and anile devotion, or whether by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arrogance and malice so that they alone may be held to possess the secrets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, I know not: this much I do know, that I find in their writings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing which has the air of a Divine secret, but only childish
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lucubrations. (66) I have read and known certain Kabbalistic triflers, whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insanity provokes my unceasing as astonishment. (67) That faults have crept
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in will, I think, be denied by no sensible person who reads the passage
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about Saul, above quoted (1 Sam. xiii:1) and also 2 Sam. vi:2: "And David
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arose and went with all the people that were with him from Judah, to bring
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: up from thence the ark of God."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) No one can fail to remark that the name of their destination, viz.,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Kirjath-jearim [Endnote 18], has been omitted: nor can we deny that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2 Sam. xiii:37, has been tampered with and mutilated. "And Absalom fled, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. (69) And he mourned for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his son every day. So Absalom fled, and went to Geshur, and was there three
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years." (70) I know that I have remarked other passages of the same kind,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but I cannot recall them at the moment.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) That the marginal notes which are found continually in the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Codices are doubtful readings will, I think, be evident to everyone who has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: noticed that they often arise from the great similarity, of some of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrew letters, such for instance, as the similarity between Kaph and Beth,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jod and Van, Daleth and Reth, &c. (72) For example, the text in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2 Sam. v:24, runs "in the time when thou hearest," and similarly in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judges xxi:22, "And it shall be when their fathers or their brothers come
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unto us often," the marginal version is "come unto us to complain."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (73) So also many various readings have arisen from the use of the letters
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: named mutes, which are generally not sounded in pronunciation, and are taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: promiscuously, one for the other. (74) For example, in Levit. xxv:29, it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written, "The house shall be established which is not in the walled city,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the margin has it, "which is in a walled city."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (75) Though these matters are self-evident, [Endnore 6], it is necessary, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answer the reasonings of certain Pharisees, by which they endeavour to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convince us that the marginal notes serve to indicate some mystery, and were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: added or pointed out by the writers of the sacred books. (76) The first of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these reasons, which, in my opinion, carries little weight, is taken from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the practice of reading the Scriptures aloud.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (77) If, it is urged, these notes were added to show various readings which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could not be decided upon by posterity, why has custom prevailed that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marginal readings should always be retained? (78) Why has the meaning which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is preferred been set down in the margin when it ought to have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: incorporated in the text, and not relegated to a side note?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (79) The second reason is more specious, and is taken from the nature of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case. (80) It is admitted that faults have crept into the sacred writings by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chance and not by design; but they say that in the five books the word for a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: girl is, with one exception, written without the letter "he," contrary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all grammatical rules, whereas in the margin it is written correctly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the universal rule of grammar. (81) Can this have happened by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistake? Is it possible to imagine a clerical error to have been committed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: every, time the word occurs? (82) Moreover, it would have been easy, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supply the emendation. (83) Hence, when these readings are not accidental
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or corrections of manifest mistakes, it is supposed that they must have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set down on purpose by the original writers, and have a meaning. (84)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, it is easy to answer such arguments; as to the question of custom
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: having prevailed in the reading of the marginal versions, I will not spare
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much time for its consideration: I know not the promptings of superstition,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and perhaps the practice may have arisen from the idea that both readings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were deemed equally good or tolerable, and therefore, lest either should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neglected, one was appointed to be written, and the other to be read. (85)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: They feared to pronounce judgment in so weighty a matter lest they should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistake the false for the true, and therefore they would give preference to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither, as they must necessarily have done if they had commanded one only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be both read and written. (86) This would be especially the case where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the marginal readings were not written down in the sacred books: or the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: custom may have originated because some things though rightly written down
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were desired to be read otherwise according to the marginal version, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the general rule was made that the marginal version should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: followed in reading the Scriptures. (87) The cause which induced the scribes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to expressly prescribe certain passages to be read in the marginal version,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will now touch on, for not all the marginal notes are various readings,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but some mark expressions which have passed out of common use, obsolete
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words and terms which current decency did not allow to be read in a public
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assembly. (88) The ancient writers, without any evil intention, employed no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courtly paraphrase, but called things by their plain names. (891)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Afterwards, through the spread of evil thoughts and luxury, words which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could be used by the ancients without offence, came to be considered
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscene. (90) There was no need for this cause to change the text of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture. (91) Still, as a concession to the popular weakness, it became
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the custom to substitute more decent terms for words denoting sexual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intercourse, exereta, &c., and to read them as they were given in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: margin.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (92) At any rate, whatever may have been the origin of the practice of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reading Scripture according to the marginal version, it was not that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true interpretation is contained therein. (93) For besides that, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Rabbins in the Talmud often differ from the Massoretes, and give other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings which they approve of, as I will shortly show, certain things are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: found in the margin which appear less warranted by the uses of the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: language. (94) For example, in 2 Samuel xiv:22, we read, "In that the king
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hath fulfilled the request of his servant," a construction plainly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regular, and agreeing with that in chap. xvi. (95) But the margin has it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "of thy servant," which does not agree with the person of the verb. (96)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: So, too, chap. xvi:25 of the same book, we find, "As if one had inquired at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the oracle of God," the margin adding "someone" to stand as a nominative to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the verb. (97) But the correction is not apparently warranted, for it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a common practice, well known to grammarians in the Hebrew language, to use
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the third person singular of the active verb impersonally.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (98) The second argument advanced by the Pharisees is easily answered from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what has just been said, namely, that the scribes besides the various
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings called attention to obsolete words. (99) For there is no doubt
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that in Hebrew as in other languages, changes of use made many words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obsolete and antiquated, and such were found by the later scribes in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sacred books and noted by them with a view to the books being publicly read
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to custom. (100) For this reason the word nahgar is always found
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marked because its gender was originally common, and it had the same meaning
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the Latin juvenis (a young person). (101) So also the Hebrew capital was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anciently called Jerusalem, not Jerusalaim. (102) As to the pronouns himself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and herself, I think that the later scribes changed vau into jod (a very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frequent change in Hebrew) when they wished to express the feminine gender,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but that the ancients only distinguished the two genders by a change of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vowels. (103) I may also remark that the irregular tenses of certain verbs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differ in the ancient and modern forms, it being formerly considered a mark
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of elegance to employ certain letters agreeable to the ear.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) In a word, I could easily multiply proofs of this kind if I were not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: afraid of abusing the patience of the reader. (105) Perhaps I shall be asked
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: how I became acquainted with the fact that all these expressions are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obsolete. (106) I reply that I have found them in the most ancient Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writers in the Bible itself, and that they have not been imitated by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subsequent authors, and thus they are recognized as antiquated, though the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: language in which they occur is dead. (107) But perhaps someone may press
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the question why, if it be true, as I say, that the marginal notes of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bible generally mark various readings, there are never more than two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings of a passage, that in the text and that in the margin, instead of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: three or more; and further, how the scribes can have hesitated between two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings, one of which is evidently contrary to grammar, and the other a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain correction.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (108) The answer to these questions also is easy: I will premise that it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: almost certain that there once were more various readings than those now
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recorded. (119) For instance, one finds many in the Talmud which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Massoretes have neglected, and are so different one from the other that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even the superstitious editor of the Bomberg Bible confesses that he cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmonize them. (110) "We cannot say anything," he writes, "except what we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said above, namely, that the Talmud is generally in contradiction to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Massorete." (111) So that we are nor bound to hold that there never were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more than two readings of any passage, yet I am willing to admit, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indeed I believe that more than two readings are never found: and for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: following reasons:-(112) (I.) The cause of the differences of reading only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admits of two, being generally the similarity of certain letters, so that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the question resolved itself into which should be written Beth, or Kaf,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jod or Vau, Daleth or Reth: cases which are constantly occurring, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frequently yielding a fairly good meaning whichever alternative be adopted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (113) Sometimes, too, it is a question whether a syllable be long or short,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quantity being determined by the letters called mutes. (114) Moreover, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never asserted that all the marginal versions, without exception, marked
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: various readings; on the contrary, we have stated that many were due to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives of decency or a desire to explain obsolete words. (115) (II.) I am
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inclined to attribute the fact that more than two readings are never found
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the paucity of exemplars, perhaps not more than two or three, found by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the scribes. (116) In the treatise of the scribes, chap. vi., mention is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made of three only, pretended to have been found in the time of Ezra, in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order that the marginal versions might be attributed to him.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (117) However that may be, if the scribes only had three codices we may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily imagine that in a given passage two of them would be in accord, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it would be extraordinary if each one of the three gave a different reading
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the same text.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (118) The dearth of copies after the time of Ezra will surprise no one who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has read the 1st chapter of Maccabees, or Josephus's "Antiquities," Bk. 12,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. 5. (119) Nay, it appears wonderful considering the fierce and daily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persecution, that even these few should have been preserved. (120) This
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will, I think, be plain to even a cursory reader of the history of those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: times.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (121) We have thus discovered the reasons why there are never more than two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings of a passage in the Bible, but this is a long way from supposing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we may therefore conclude that the Bible was purposely written
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: incorrectly in such passages in order to signify some mystery. (122) As to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the second argument, that some passages are so faultily written that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are at plain variance with all grammar, and should have been corrected in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the text and not in the margin, I attach little weight to it, for I am not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerned to say what religious motive the scribes may have had for acting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they did: possibly they did so from candour, wishing to transmit the few
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exemplars of the Bible which they had found exactly in their original state,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marking the differences they discovered in the margin, not as doubtful
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings, but as simple variants. (123) I have myself called them doubtful
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings, because it would be generally impossible to say which of the two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: versions is preferable.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (124) Lastly, besides these doubtful readings the scribes have (by leaving a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hiatus in the middle of a paragraph) marked several passages as mutilated.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (125) The Massoretes have counted up such instances, and they amount to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eight-and-twenty. (126) I do not know whether any mystery is thought to lurk
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the number, at any rate the Pharisees religiously preserve a certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: amount of empty space.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (127) One of such hiatus occurs (to give an instance) in Gen. iv:8, where it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is written, "And Cain said to his brother . . . . and it came to pass while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they were in the field, &c.," a space being left in which we should expect
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to hear what it was that Cain said.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (128) Similarly there are (besides those points we have noticed)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eight-and-twenty hiatus left by the scribes. (129) Many of these would not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be recognized as mutilated if it were not for the empty space left. But I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said enough on this subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER X. - AN EXAMINATION OF THE REMAINING BOOKS OF
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: THE OLD TESTAMENT ACCORDING TO THE PRECEDING METHOD.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) I now pass on to the remaining books of the Old Testament. (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Concerning the two books of Chronicles I have nothing particular or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important to remark, except that they were certainly written after the time
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Ezra, and possibly after the restoration of the Temple by Judas
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Maccabaeus [Endnote 19]. (2) For in chap. ix. of the first book we find a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reckoning of the families who were the first to live in Jerusalem, and in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: verse 17 the names of the porters, of which two recur in Nehemiah. (3) This
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shows that the books were certainly compiled after the rebuilding of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: city. (4) As to their actual writer, their authority, utility, and doctrine,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I come to no conclusion. (5) I have always been astonished that they have
