title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been included in the Bible by men who shut out from the canon the books of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wisdom, Tobit, and the others styled apocryphal. (6) I do not aim at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disparaging their authority, but as they are universally received I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: leave them as they are.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) The Psalms were collected and divided into five books in the time of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: second temple, for Ps. lxxxviii. was published, according to Philo-Judaeus,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while king Jehoiachin was still a prisoner in Babylon; and Ps. lxxxix. when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same king obtained his liberty: I do not think Philo would have made the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: statement unless either it had been the received opinion in his time, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else had been told him by trustworthy persons.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (8) The Proverbs of Solomon were, I believe, collected at the same time, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at least in the time of King Josiah; for in chap. xxv:1, it is written,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "These are also proverbs of Solomon which the men of Hezekiah, king of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judah, copied out." (9) I cannot here pass over in silence the audacity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Rabbis who wished to exclude from the sacred canon both the Proverbs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Ecclesiastes, and to put them both in the Apocrypha. (10) In fact, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would actually have done so, if they had not lighted on certain passages in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the law of Moses is extolled. (11) It is, indeed, grievous to think
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the settling of the sacred canon lay in the hands of such men; however,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I congratulate them, in this instance, on their suffering us to see these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books in question, though I cannot refrain from doubting whether they have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transmitted them in absolute good faith; but I will not now linger on this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (10) I pass on, then, to the prophetic books. (11) An examination of these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assures me that the prophecies therein contained have been compiled from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other books, and are not always set down in the exact order in which they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were spoken or written by the prophets, but are only such as were collected
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here and there, so that they are but fragmentary.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) Isaiah began to prophecy in the reign of Uzziah, as the writer himself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: testifies in the first verse. (13) He not only prophesied at that time, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: furthermore wrote the history of that king (see 2 Chron. xxvi:22) in a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: volume now lost. (13) That which we possess, we have shown to have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: taken from the chronicles of the kings of Judah and Israel.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (14) We may add that the Rabbis assert that this prophet prophesied in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign of Manasseh, by whom he was eventually put to death, and, although
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this seems to be a myth, it yet shows that they did not think that all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isaiah's prophecies are extant.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (15) The prophecies of Jeremiah, which are related historically are also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: taken from various chronicles; for not only are they heaped together
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusedly, without any account being taken of dates, but also the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: story is told in them differently in different passages. (16) For instance,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in chap. xxi. we are told that the cause of Jeremiah's arrest was that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had prophesied the destruction of the city to Zedekiah who consulted him.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17) This narrative suddenly passes, in chap xxii., to the prophet's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remonstrances to Jehoiakim (Zedekiah's predecessor), and the prediction he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made of that king's captivity; then, in chap. xxv., come the revelations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted to the prophet previously, that is in the fourth year of Jehoiakim,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, further on still, the revelations received in the first year of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same reign. (18) The continuator of Jeremiah goes on heaping prophecy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: upon prophecy without any regard to dates, until at last, in chap. xxxviii.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (as if the intervening chapters had been a parenthesis), he takes up the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thread dropped in chap. xxi.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19) In fact, the conjunction with which chap. xxxviii. begins, refers to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the 8th, 9th, and 10th verses of chap. xxi. Jeremiah's last arrest is then
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very differently described, and a totally separate cause is given for his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: daily retention in the court of the prison.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20) We may thus clearly see that these portions of the book have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compiled from various sources, and are only from this point of view
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehensible. (21) The prophecies contained in the remaining chapters,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where Jeremiah speaks in the first person, seem to be taken from a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book written by Baruch, at Jeremiah's dictation. (22) These, however, only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprise (as appears from chap. xxxvi:2) the prophecies revealed to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet from the time of Josiah to the fourth year of Jehoiakim, at which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: period the book begins. (23) The contents of chap. xlv:2, on to chap.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: li:59, seem taken from the same volume.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) That the book of Ezekiel is only a fragment, is clearly indicated by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the first verse. (25) For anyone may see that the conjunction with which it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: begins, refers to something already said, and connects what follows
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therewith. (26) However, not only this conjunction, but the whole text
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the discourse implies other writings. (27) The fact of the present work
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beginning the thirtieth year shows that the prophet is continuing, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commencing a discourse; and this is confirmed by the writer, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parenthetically states in verse 3, "The word of the Lord came often unto
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ezekiel the priest, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans," as if to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say that the prophecies which he is about to relate are the sequel to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelations formerly received by Ezekiel from God. (28) Furthermore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Josephus, 11 Antiq." x:9, says that Ezekiel prophesied that Zedekiah should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not see Babylon, whereas the book we now have not only contains no such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: statement, but contrariwise asserts in chap. xvii. that he should be taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to Babylon as a captive, [Endnote 20].
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (29) Of Hosea I cannot positively state that he wrote more than is now
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extant in the book bearing his name, but I am astonished at the smallness of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the quantity, we possess, for the sacred writer asserts that the prophet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophesied for more than eighty years.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) We may assert, speaking generally, that the compiler of the prophetic
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books neither collected all the prophets, nor all the writings of those we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have; for of the prophets who are said to have prophesied in the reign of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Manasseh and of whom general mention is made in 2 Chron. xxxiii:10, 18, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have, evidently, no prophecies extant; neither have we all the prophecies of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the twelve who give their names to books. (31) Of Jonah we have only, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy concerning the Ninevites, though he also prophesied to the children
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Israel, as we learn in 2 Kings xiv:25.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) The book and the personality of Job have caused much controversy. (33)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Some think that the book is the work of Moses, and the whole narrative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely allegorical. (34) Such is the opinion of the Rabbins recorded in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Talmud, and they are supported by, Maimonides in his "More Nebuchim." (35)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Others believe it to be a true history, and some suppose that Job lived in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the time of Jacob, and was married to his daughter Dinah. (36) Aben Ezra,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, as I have already stated, affirms, in his commentaries, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: work is a translation into Hebrew from some other language: I could wish
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he could advance more cogent arguments than he does, for we might then
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclude that the Gentiles also had sacred books. (37) I myself leave the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter undecided, but I conjecture Job to have been a Gentile, and a man of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very stable character, who at first prospered, then was assailed with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: terrible calamities, and finally, was restored to great happiness. (38) (He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is thus named, among others, by Ezekiel, xiv:12.) (39) I take it that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constancy of his mind amid the vicissitudes of his fortune occasioned many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men to dispute about God's providence, or at least caused the writer of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book in question to compose his dialogues; for the contents, and also the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: style, seem to emanate far less from a man wretchedly ill and lying among
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ashes, than from one reflecting at ease in his study. (40) I should also be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inclined to agree with Aben Ezra that the book is a translation, for its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: poetry seems akin to that of the Gentiles; thus the Father of Gods summons a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: council, and Momus, here called Satan, criticizes the Divine decrees with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the utmost freedom. (41) But these are mere conjectures without any solid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundation.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) I pass on to the book of Daniel, which, from chap. viii. onwards,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undoubtedly contains the writing of Daniel himself. (43) Whence the first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seven chapters are derived I cannot say; we may, however, conjecture that,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they were first written in Chaldean, they are taken from Chaldean
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chronicles. (44) If this could be proved, it would form a very striking
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proof of the fact that the sacredness of Scripture depends on our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding of the doctrines therein signified, and not on the words, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: language, and the phrases in which these doctrines are conveyed to us;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and it would further show us that books which teach and speak of whatever is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest and best are equally sacred, whatever be the tongue in which they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are written, or the nation to which they belong.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) We can, however, in this case only remark that the chapters in question
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were written in Chaldee, and yet are as sacred as the rest of the Bible.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (46) The first book of Ezra is so intimately connected with the book of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Daniel that both are plainly recognizable as the work of the same author,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writing of Jewish history from the time of the first captivity onwards. (47)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have no hesitation in joining to this the book of Esther, for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conjunction with which it begins can refer to nothing else. (48) It cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be the same work as that written by Mordecai, for, in chap. ix:20-22,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another person relates that Mordecai wrote letters, and tells us their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contents; further, that Queen Esther confirmed the days of Purim in their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: times appointed, and that the decree was written in the book that is (by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebraism), in a book known to all then living, which, as Aben Ezra and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest confess, has now perished. (49) Lastly, for the rest of the acts of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Mordecai, the historian refers us to the chronicles of the kings of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Persia. (50) Thus there is no doubt that this book was written by the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: person as he who recounted the history of Daniel and Ezra, and who wrote
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nehemiah, [Endnote 21], sometimes called the second book of Ezra. (51) We
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may, then, affirm that all these books are from one hand; but we have no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clue whatever to the personality of the author. (52) However, in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determine whence he, whoever he was, had gained a knowledge of the histories
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he had, perchance, in great measure himself written, we may remark
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the governors or chiefs of the Jews, after the restoration of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Temple, kept scribes or historiographers, who wrote annals or chronicles of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them. (53) The chronicles of the kings are often quoted in the books of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Kings, but the chronicles of the chiefs and priests are quoted for the first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time in Nehemiah xii:23, and again in 1 Macc. xvi:24. (54) This is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undoubtedly the book referred to as containing the decree of Esther and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acts of Mordecai; and which, as we said with Aben Ezra, is now lost. (55)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: From it were taken the whole contents of these four books, for no other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority is quoted by their writer, or is known to us.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (56) That these books were not written by either Ezra or Nehemiah is plain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Nehemiah xii:9, where the descendants of the high priest, Joshua are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: traced down to Jaddua, the sixth high priest, who went to meet Alexander the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Great, when the Persian empire was almost subdued (Josephus, "Ant." ii.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 108), or who, according to Philo-Judaeus, was the sixth and last high priest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the Persians. (57) In the same chapter of Nehemiah, verse 22, this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point is clearly brought out: "The Levites in the days of Eliashib, Joiada,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Johanan, and Jaddua, were recorded chief of the fathers: also the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priests, to the reign of Darius the Persian" - that is to say, in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chronicles; and, I suppose, no one thinks, [Endnote 22],  that the lives of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nehemiah and Ezra were so prolonged that they outlived fourteen kings of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Persia. (58) Cyrus was the first who granted the Jews permission to rebuild
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their Temple: the period between his time and Darius, fourteenth and last
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king of Persia, extends over 230 years. (59) I have, therefore, no doubt
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that these books were written after Judas Maccabaeus had restored the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship in the Temple, for at that time false books of Daniel, Ezra, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Esther were published by evil-disposed persons, who were almost certainly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Sadducees, for the writings were never recognized by the Pharisees, so far
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I am aware; and, although certain myths in the fourth book of Ezra are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repeated in the Talmud, they must not be set down to the Pharisees, for all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the most ignorant admit that they have been added by some trifler: in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, I think, someone must have made such additions with a view to casting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ridicule on all the traditions of the sect.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) Perhaps these four books were written out and published at the time I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have mentioned with a view to showing the people that the prophecies of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Daniel had been fulfilled, and thus kindling their piety, and awakening a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hope of future deliverance in the midst of their misfortunes. (61) In
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spite of their recent origin, the books before us contain many errors, due,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I suppose, to the haste with which they were written. (62) Marginal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readings, such as I have mentioned in the last chapter, are found here as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: elsewhere, and in even greater abundance; there are, moreover, certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages which can only be accounted for by supposing some such cause as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hurry.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) However, before calling attention to the marginal readings, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remark that, if the Pharisees are right in supposing them to have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ancient, and the work of the original scribes, we must perforce admit that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these scribes (if there were more than one) set them down because they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: found that the text from which they were copying was inaccurate, and did yet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not venture to alter what was written by their predecessors and superiors.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (64) I need not again go into the subject at length, and will, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proceed to mention some discrepancies not noticed in the margin.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) I. Some error has crept into the text of the second chapter of Ezra,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for in verse 64 we are told that the total of all those mentioned in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of the chapter amounts to 42,360; but, when we come to add up the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several items we get as result only 29,818. (66) There must, therefore, be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an error, either in the total, or in the details. (67) The total is probably
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: correct, for it would most likely be well known to all as a noteworthy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing; but with the details, the case would be different. (68) If, then, any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: error had crept into the total, it would at once have been remarked, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily corrected. (69) This view is confirmed by Nehemiah vii., where this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chapter of Ezra is mentioned, and a total is given in plain correspondence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereto; but the details are altogether different - some are larger, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some less, than those in Ezra, and altogether they amount to 31,089.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (70) We may, therefore, conclude that both in Ezra and in Nehemiah the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: details are erroneously given. (71) The commentators who attempt to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmonize these evident contradictions draw on their imagination, each to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the best of his ability; and while professing adoration for each letter and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: word of Scripture, only succeed in holding up the sacred writers to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ridicule, as though they knew not how to write or relate a plain narrative.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (72) Such persons effect nothing but to render the clearness of Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscure. (73) If the Bible could everywhere be interpreted after their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashion, there would be no such thing as a rational statement of which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the meaning could be relied on. (74) However, there is no need to dwell on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the subject; only I am convinced that if any historian were to attempt to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imitate the proceedings freely attributed to the writers of the Bible, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commentators would cover him with contempt. (75) If it be blasphemy to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assert that there are any errors in Scripture, what name shall we apply to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who foist into it their own fancies, who degrade the sacred writers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: till they seem to write confused nonsense, and who deny the plainest and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most evident meanings? (76) What in the whole Bible can be plainer than the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact that Ezra and his companions, in the second chapter of the book
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributed to him, have given in detail the reckoning of all the Hebrews who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set out with them for Jerusalem? (77) This is proved by the reckoning being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given, not only of those who told their lineage, but also of those who were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to do so. (78) Is it not equally clear from Nehemiah vii:5, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writer merely there copies the list given in Ezra? (79) Those, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who explain these pas sages otherwise, deny the plain meaning of Scripture -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nay, they deny Scripture itself. (80) They think it pious to reconcile one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passage of Scripture with another - a pretty piety, forsooth, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accommodates the clear passages to the obscure, the correct to the faulty,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sound to the corrupt.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) Far be it from me to call such commentators blasphemers, if their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives be pure: for to err is human. But I return to my subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (82) Besides these errors in numerical details, there are others in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: genealogies, in the history, and, I fear also in the prophecies. (83) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy of Jeremiah (chap. xxii.), concerning Jechoniah, evidently does not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree with his history, as given in I Chronicles iii:17-19, and especially
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the last words of the chapter, nor do I see how the prophecy, "thou
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shalt die in peace," can be applied to Zedekiah, whose eyes were dug out
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after his sons had been slain before him. (84) If prophecies are to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreted by their issue, we must make a change of name, and read
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jechoniah for Zedekiah, and vice versa (85) This, however, would be too
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: paradoxical a proceeding; so I prefer to leave the matter unexplained,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially as the error, if error there be, must be set down to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian, and not to any fault in the authorities.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (86) Other difficulties I will not touch upon, as I should only weary the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reader, and, moreover, be repeating the remarks of other writers. (87) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: R. Selomo, in face of the manifest contradiction in the above-mentioned
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: genealogies, is compelled to break forth into these words (see his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commentary on 1 Chron. viii.): "Ezra (whom he supposes to be the author of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the book of Chronicles) gives different names and a different genealogy to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sons of Benjamin from those which we find in Genesis, and describes most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Levites differently from Joshua, because he found original
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discrepancies." (88) And, again, a little later: "The genealogy of Gibeon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and others is described twice in different ways, from different tables of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each genealogy, and in writing them down Ezra adopted the version given in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the majority of the texts, and when the authority was equal he gave both."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (89) Thus granting that these books were compiled from sources originally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: incorrect and uncertain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (90) In fact the commentators, in seeking to harmonize difficulties,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generally do no more than indicate their causes: for I suppose no sane
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: person supposes that the sacred historians deliberately wrote with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of appearing to contradict themselves freely. (91) Perhaps I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall be told that I am overthrowing the authority of Scripture, for that,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to me, anyone may suspect it of error in any passage; but, on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary, I have shown that my object has been to prevent the clear and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncorrupted passages being accommodated to and corrupted by the faulty ones;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither does the fact that some passages are corrupt warrant us in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspecting all. (92) No book ever was completely free from faults, yet I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would ask, who suspects all books to be everywhere faulty? (93) Surely no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one, especially when the phraseology is clear and the intention of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: author plain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) I have now finished the task I set myself with respect to the books of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Old Testament. (95) We may easily conclude from what has been said, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before the time of the Maccabees there was no canon of sacred books,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 23], but that those which we now possess were selected from a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: multitude of others at the period of the restoration of the Temple by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharisees (who also instituted the set form of prayers), who are alone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: responsible for their acceptance. (96) Those, therefore, who would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrate the authority of Holy Scripture, are bound to show the authority
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of each separate book; it is not enough to prove the Divine origin of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: single book in order to infer the Divine origin of the rest. (97) In that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case we should have to assume that the council of Pharisees was, in its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: choice of books, infallible, and this could never be proved. (98) I am led
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to assert that the Pharisees alone selected the books of the Old Testament,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and inserted them in the canon, from the fact that in Daniel ii. is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proclaimed the doctrine of the Resurrection, which the Sadducees denied;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, furthermore, the Pharisees plainly assert in the Talmud that they so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: selected them. (99) For in the treatise of Sabbathus, chapter ii., folio 30,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: page 2, it is written: R. Jehuda, surnamed Rabbi, reports that the experts
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished to conceal the book of Ecclesiastes because they found therein words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opposed to the law (that is, to the book of the law of Moses). (100) Why did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they not hide it? (101) "Because it begins in accordance with the law, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ends according to the law;" and a little further on we read: "They sought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also to conceal the book of Proverbs." (102) And in the first chapter of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same treatise, fol. 13, page 2: "Verily, name one man for good, even he who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was called Neghunja, the son of Hezekiah: for, save for him, the book of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ezekiel would been concealed, because it agreed not with the words of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (103) It is thus abundantly clear that men expert in the law summoned a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: council to decide which books should be received into the canon, and which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excluded. (104) If any man, therefore, wishes to be certified as to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority of all the books, let him call a fresh council, and ask every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: member his reasons.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (105) The time has now come for examining in the same manner the books in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the New Testament; but as I learn that the task has been already performed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by men highly skilled in science and languages, and as I do not myself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess a knowledge of Greek sufficiently exact for the task; lastly, as we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have lost the originals of those books which were written in Hebrew, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prefer to decline the undertaking. (106) However, I will touch on those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: points which have most bearing on my subject in the following chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: End of Part 2.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AUTHOR'S ENDNOTES TO THE THEOLOGICO-POLITICAL TREATISE
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Part 2 - Chapters VI to X
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER VI.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 6. (1) We doubt of the existence of God, and consequently of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all else, so long as we have no clear and distinct idea of God, but only a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confused one. (2) For as he who knows not rightly the nature of a triangle,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knows not that its three angles are equal to two right angles, so he who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives the Divine nature confusedly, does not see that it pertains to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of God to exist. (3) Now, to conceive the nature of God clearly and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly, it is necessary to pay attention to a certain number of very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simple notions, called general notions, and by their help to associate the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceptions which we form of the attributes of the Divine nature. (4) It
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, for the first time, becomes clear to us, that God exists necessarily,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He is omnipresent, and that all our conceptions involve in themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of God and are conceived through it. (5) Lastly, we see that all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our adequate ideas are true. (6) Compare on this point the prolegomena to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book, "Principles of Descartes's philosophy set forth geometrically."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER VII.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 7. (1) "It is impossible to find a method which would enable us to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gain a certain knowledge of all the statements in Scripture." (2) I mean
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible for us who have not the habitual use of the language, and have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lost the precise meaning of its phraseology.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 8. (1) "Not in things whereof the understanding can gain a clear and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct idea, and which are conceivable through themselves." (2) By things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceivable I mean not only those which are rigidly proved, but also those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof we are morally certain, and are wont to hear without wonder, though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are incapable of proof. (3) Everyone can see the truth of Euclid's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: propositions before they are proved. (4) So also the histories of things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: both future and past which do not surpass human credence, laws,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: institutions, manners, I call conceivable and clear, though they cannot be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved mathematically. (5) But hieroglyphics and histories which seem to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass the bounds of belief I call inconceivable; yet even among these last
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there are many which our method enables us to investigate, and to discover
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the meaning of their narrator.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER VIII.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 9. (1) "Mount Moriah is called the mount of God." (2) That is by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian, not by Abraham, for he says that the place now called "In the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mount of the Lord it shall be revealed," was called by Abraham, "the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall provide."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 10. (1) "Before that territory [Idumoea] was conquered by David."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2) From this time to the reign of Jehoram when they again separated from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jewish kingdom (2 Kings viii:20), the Idumaeans had no king, princes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appointed by the Jews supplied the place of kings (1 Kings xxii:48), in fact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prince of Idumaea is called a king (2 Kings iii:9).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) It may be doubted whether the last of the Idumaean kings had begun to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign before the accession of Saul, or whether Scripture in this chapter of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Genesis wished to enumerate only such kings as were independent. (4) It is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evidently mere trifling to wish to enrol among Hebrew kings the name of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, who set up a dominion entirely different from a monarchy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER IX.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 11. (1) "With few exceptions." (2) One of these exceptions is found
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in 2 Kings xviii:20, where we read, "Thou sayest (but they are but vain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words)," the second person being used. (3) In Isaiah xxxvi:5, we read "I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say (but they are but vain words) I have counsel and strength for war," and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the twenty-second verse of the chapter in Kings it is written, "But if ye
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say," the plural number being used, whereas Isaiah gives the singular. (4)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The text in Isaiah does not contain the words found in 2 Kings xxxii:32. (5)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus there are several cases of various readings where it is impossible to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguish the best.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 12. (1) "The expressions in the two passages are so varied." (2) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance we read in 2 Sam. vii:6, "But I have walked in a tent and in a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tabernacle." (3) Whereas in 1 Chron. xvii:5, "but have gone from tent to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tent and from one tabernacle to another." (4) In 2 Sam. vii:10, we read, "to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: afflict them," whereas in 1 Chron. vii:9, we find a different expression. (5)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I could point out other differences still greater, but a single reading of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chapters in question will suffice to make them manifest to all who are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither blind nor devoid of sense.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 13. (1) "This time cannot refer to what immediately precedes." (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is plain from the context that this passage must allude to the time when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joseph was sold by his brethren. (3) But this is not all. (4) We may draw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same conclusion from the age of Judah, who was than twenty-two years old
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at most, taking as basis of calculation his own history just narrated. (5)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It follows, indeed, from the last verse of Gen. xxx., that Judah was born in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the tenth of the years of Jacob's servitude to Laban, and Joseph in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fourteenth. (6) Now, as we know that Joseph was seventeen years old when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sold by his brethren, Judah was then not more than twenty-one. (7) Hence,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those writers who assert that Judah's long absence from his father's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: house took place before Joseph was sold, only seek to delude themselves and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to call in question the Scriptural authority which they are anxious to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: protect.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 14. (1) "Dinah was scarcely seven years old when she was violated by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Schechem." (2) The opinion held by some that Jacob wandered about eight or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ten years between Mesopotamia and Bethel, savours of the ridiculous; if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect for Aben Ezra, allows me to say so. (3) For it is clear that Jacob
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had two reasons for haste: first, the desire to see his old parents;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secondly, and chiefly to perform, the vow made when he fled from his brother
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Gen. xxviii:10 and xxxi:13, and xxxv:1). (4) We read (Gen. xxxi:3), that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God had commanded him to fulfill his vow, and promised him help for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: returning to his country. (5) If these considerations seem conjectures
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than reasons, I will waive the point and admit that Jacob, more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unfortunate than Ulysses, spent eight or ten years or even longer, in this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: short journey. (6) At any rate it cannot be denied that Benjamin was born in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the last year of this wandering, that is by the reckoning of the objectors,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when Joseph was sixteen or seventeen years old, for Jacob left Laban seven
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years after Joseph's birth. (7) Now from the seventeenth year of Joseph's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: age till the patriarch went into Egypt, not more than twenty-two years
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: elapsed, as we have shown in this chapter. (8) Consequently Benjamin, at the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time of the journey to Egypt, was twenty-three or twenty- four at the most.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) He would therefore have been a grandfather in the flower of his age
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Gen. xlvi:21, cf. Numb. xxvi:38, 40, and 1 Chron. viii:1), for it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain that Bela, Benjamin's eldest son, had at that time, two sons, Addai
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Naa-man. (10) This is just as absurd as the statement that Dinah was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: violated at the age of seven, not to mention other impossibilities
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would result from the truth of the narrative. (11) Thus we see that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unskillful endeavours to solve difficulties, only raise fresh ones, and make
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusion worse confounded.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 15. (1) "Othniel, son of Kenag, was judge for forty years." (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Rabbi Levi Ben Gerson and others believe that these forty years which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bible says were passed in freedom, should be counted from the death of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua, and consequently include the eight years during which the people
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were subject to Kushan Rishathaim, while the following eighteen years
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be added on to the eighty years of Ehud's and Shamgar's judgeships. (3)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In this case it would be necessary to reckon the other years of subjection
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among those said by the Bible to have been passed in freedom. (4) But the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bible expressly notes the number of years of subjection, and the number of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years of freedom, and further declares (Judges ii:18) that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrew state was prosperous during the whole time of the judges. (5)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore it is evident that Levi Ben Gerson (certainly a very learned man),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and those who follow him, correct rather than interpret the Scriptures.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) The same fault is committed by those who assert, that Scripture, by this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general calculation of years, only intended to mark the period of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regular administration of the Hebrew state, leaving out the years of anarchy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and subjection as periods of misfortune and interregnum. (7) Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly passes over in silence periods of anarchy, but does not, as they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dream, refuse to reckon them or wipe them out of the country's annals. (8)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is clear that Ezra, in 1 Kings vi., wished to reckon absolutely all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: years since the flight from Egypt. (9) This is so plain, that no one versed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the Scriptures can doubt it. (10) For, without going back to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precise words of the text, we may see that the genealogy of David given at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the end of the book of Ruth, and I Chron. ii., scarcely accounts for so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great a number of years. (11) For Nahshon, who was prince of the tribe of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judah (Numb. vii:11), two years after the Exodus, died in the desert, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his son Salmon passed the Jordan with Joshua. (12) Now this Salmon,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the genealogy, was David's great-grandfather. (13) Deducting,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, from the total of 480 years, four years for Solomon's reign, seventy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for David's life, and forty for the time passed in the desert, we find that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: David was born 366 years after the passage of the Jordan. (14) Hence we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must believe that David's father, grandfather, great-grandfather, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great-great-grandfather begat children when they were ninety years old.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 16. (1) "Samson was judge for twenty years." (2) Samson was born
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after the Hebrews had fallen under the dominion of the Philistines.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 17. (1) Otherwise, they rather correct than explain Scripture.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 18. (1) "Kirjath-jearim." Kirjath-jearim is also called Baale of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judah. (2) Hence Kimchi and others think that the words Baale Judah, which I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have translated "the people of Judah," are the name of a town. (3) But this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not so, for the word Baale is in the plural. (4) Moreover, comparing this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: text in Samuel with I Chron. Xiii:5, we find that David did not rise up
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and go forth out of Baale, but that he went thither. (5) If the author of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the book of Samuel had meant to name the place whence David took the ark, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would, if he spoke Hebrew correctly, have said, "David rose up, and set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth from Baale Judah, and took the ark from thence."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER X.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 19. (1) "After the restoration of the Temple by Judas Maccaboeus."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2) This conjecture, if such it be, is founded on the genealogy of King
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeconiah, given in 1 Chron. iii., which finishes at the sons of Elioenai,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thirteenth in direct descent from him: whereon we must observe that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeconiah, before his captivity, had no children; but it is probable that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had two while he was in prison, if we may draw any inference from the names
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he gave them. (3) As to his grandchildren, it is evident that they were born
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after his deliverance, if the names be any guide, for his grandson, Pedaiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (a name meaning God hath delivered me), who, according to this chapter, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the father of Zerubbabel, was born in the thirty-seventh or thirty-eighth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: year of Jeconiah's life, that is thirty-three years before the restoration
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of liberty to the Jews by Cyrus. (4) Therefore Zerubbabel, to whom Cyrus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gave the principality of Judaea, was thirteen or fourteen years old. (5) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we need not carry the inquiry so far: we need only read attentively
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chapter of 1 Chron., already quoted, where (v. 17, sqq.) mention is made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of all the posterity of Jeconiah, and compare it with the Septuagint version
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to see clearly that these books were not published, till after Maccabaeus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had restored the Temple, the sceptre no longer belonging to the house of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeconiah.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 20. (1) "Zedekiah should be taken to Babylon." (2) No one could then
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have suspected that the prophecy of Ezekiel contradicted that of Jeremiah,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the suspicion occurs to everyone who reads the narrative of Josephus.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) The event proved that both prophets were in the right.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 21. (1) "And who wrote Nehemiah." (2) That the greater part of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book of Nehemiah was taken from the work composed by the prophet Nehemiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, follows from the testimony of its author. (See chap. i.). (3) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is obvious that the whole of the passage contained between chap. viii.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and chap. xii. verse 26, together with the two last verses of chap. xii.,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which form a sort of parenthesis to Nehemiah's words, were added by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: historian himself, who outlived Nehemiah.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 22. (1) "I suppose no one thinks" that Ezra was the uncle of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first high priest, named Joshua (see Ezra vii., and 1 Chron. vi:14), and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: went to Jerusalem from Babylon with Zerubbabel (see Nehemiah xii:1). (2) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it appears that when he saw, that the Jews were in a state of anarchy, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: returned to Babylon, as also did others (Nehem. i:2), and remained there
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: till the reign of Artaxerxes, when his requests were granted and he went a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: second time to Jerusalem. (3) Nehemiah also went to Jerusalem with Zerubbabel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the time of Cyrus (Ezra ii:2 and 63, cf. x:9, and Nehemiah x:1). (4) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: version given of the Hebrew word, translated "ambassador," is not supported
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by any authority, while it is certain that fresh names were given to those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jews who frequented the court. (5) Thus Daniel was named Balteshazzar,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Zerubbabel Sheshbazzar (Dan. i:7). (6) Nehemiah was called Atirsata,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while in virtue of his office he was styled governor, or president.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Nehem. v. 24, xii:26.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 23. (1) "Before the time of the Maccabees there was no canon of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sacred books." (2) The synagogue styled "the great" did not begin before the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjugation of Asia by the Macedonians. (3) The contention of Maimonides,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Rabbi Abraham, Ben-David, and others, that the presidents of this synagogue
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were Ezra, Daniel, Nehemiah, Haggai, Zechariah, &c., is a pure fiction,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: resting only on rabbinical tradition. (4) Indeed they assert that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion of the Persians only lasted thirty-four years, and this is their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chief reason for maintaining that the decrees of the "great synagogue," or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: synod (rejected by the Sadducees, but accepted by the Pharisees) were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ratified by the prophets, who received them from former prophets, and so in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: direct succession from Moses, who received them from God Himself. (5) Such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the doctrine which the Pharisees maintain with their wonted obstinacy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) Enlightened persons, however, who know the reasons for the convoking of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: councils, or synods, and are no strangers to the differences between
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharisees and Sadducees, can easily divine the causes which led to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assembling of this great synagogue. (7) It is very certain that no prophet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was there present, and that the decrees of the Pharisees, which they style
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their traditions, derive all their authority from it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: End of Endnotes to Part II. - Chapters VI to X.
